39448589.review:
Something about this game is both mesmerising and extremely unsettling. The audio and visuals match perfctly and the rythm gets me right in my chest every single time. I first saw the game on you tube and it doesn't do it justice. I highly reccomend experiencing this masterpiece for yourself. 

One thing I found so alluring about this game is the way it makes you feel both powerful and vulnerable at the same time. The unsettling build up to bosses which send shivers up your spine in anticipation are beautifully placed. The minimalistic design is an interesting and, in my opinion, a great choice, simple yet just enough detail to keep the eye entertained when the break periods come, but not so much that it distracts from the gameplay. Last little detail I loved are the little break periods which come once every level, they really do give your brain, eyes and hands a much needed rest which was a nice touch.

Final bit about the technical aspects of the game, I have one tiny complaint and It's that sometimes turns are hard to see when you're in tunnels if there are 2 or more one after another. Though I will admit that as the game progresses and your skills improve you'll start to pick up on audio cues telling you which obstacles and how many are ahead of you. Other than that, the controls are a dream, easy to catch on to and a challenge to master. a nice balance of difficulty and fun.

All in all and absolutely incredible game to test your reaction times and skills in a fun and exhillerating way. A work of art. Enjoy!

39189584.review:
I only looked a little into the game before buying. I wanted to experience most of it myself. But the game didn't turn out how I was expecting. The first surprise is that this game is very hard. There are only 9 levels and a final boss, and the game starts getting hard around level 4. The next surprise is that it isn't really comparable to other rhythm games. The songs are minimalist, the rhythm of your actions doesn't always fit the beat, and you can't always see what's coming ahead of time. It also gets blisteringly fast. So the game is more based on trial-and-error. Trying to compare it to a rhythm game doesn't make it look good, either.

Custom Songs? No.
Modding? No.
Playing songs on different speeds? Practice mode? No.
Multiplayer? No.
Plans for more content? None at this time.

This is why I think it's better to think of the game as an experimental indie game, with an emphasis on the experience. The visuals and music definitely make for a strange experience. I haven't beaten the game yet, and I don't know if I will. I'm on Level 7. However, some people have really gotten into this game. Some people can S-Rank the hardest stages. But for me, it's too hard.

39001886.review:
Coming from someone who never plays rhythm games, Thumper was awesome. The first day I played it was the most fun I've had in a game in awhile.

Mechanics are simple, straightforward, very visible in levels, and very satisfying (especially perfect turns).
You can clearly tell how each death is your fault, and that's great. No stupid RNG or unreasonable sequences.

Level design is absolutely stellar. They don't just throw bullshit at you left and right and expect you to have perfect reaction time. Intuitive and sensible patterns are established in early levels, then reused and adapted in different orders for later levels.

The difficulty progression (difficulty relating to the order and density of sequences and the difficulty of sequences used) is incredibly smooth. There wasn't a single arbitrary difficulty spike in any level transition. Bosses were great; hard but reasonable.

Last but not least, the aesthetic. The intense, grating, horrific visuals and audio are beautifully unique for the genre, and they really take Thumper far. Having your senses assaulted feels great.

38953267.review:
This game is basically perfect.

I'm not joking.

It's one of the few games that lives up to and then goes beyond your expectations, and the game description says EXACTLY what it is (isn't that a shocker). It's a horror themed rhythm game that makes you feel like you are on a rollercoaster avoiding hard to visually decipher obstacles, asking you to pick up on audio cues for the much needed assistance. I maintain you could play this game with the sound off even and have a good time, but it would be much much more difficult, and trust me when I say you don't want this game to be more difficult... It's a ball-breaker, and if merely beating the game wasn't hard enough, the true and blue gamer in you will be upset with the meagre score you got, and you will end up demanding that you replay the whole game, chapter by chapter enhancing your chapter scores, which is a motivational practice games haven't used since the atari days... or I guess just... other rhythm games...

To close out my review, the game is entirely enjoyable because of the bizarre nature of the aesthetic and theme, and is the most solid action-rhythm game I have ever played... If you like rhythm games, it is a must have. If you like mechanically solid games, it is a must have. If you like interesting themes, sound, atmosphere, and aesthetic, it is a must have. It is a game where I am convinced the only people who would not recommend this game are baby-people that can't beat the second chapter...

Buy this game, play it, beat it, beat it again and raise your high score, and then tell me you weren't rewarded for your time and effort. I dare you.

38950118.review:
This game will make you sweat, it will make you cry, it will give you boosts of adrenaline, and it will make you feel like a king. It does a great job at being a rhythm game while also innovating with new features and mechanics on every level. At first you might feel that the game is pretty easy, but trust me when I say that it gets a lot more difficult around halfway through playing. The speed, tempo of everything increases rapidly and you'll be begging for mercy.

I wish I had given this game a try earlier, because it was well worth the purchase. Despite being developed by only one programmer and one composer it manages to look, sound, and play great. It's like a fever dream except it has all the annoying aspects of it removed.

[b]TL;DR[/b] this is a great rhythm, fast action-paced game with a high difficulty skill ceiling on the later levels and with very rewarding gameplay.

38948536.review: Thumper is a fast-paced, anxiety inducing, and most importantly, satisfying, rhythm game that requires moderate reaction times and persistance in order to complete it thoroughly. The game exudes a deep sense of satisfaction through its fluid, responsive movement and bassy, catchy soundtrack without being overbearing on the player. It also has intuitive movement mechanics that add an even deeper layer of immersion to the almost trancelike level design. I have witnessed many fellow players comment on the high difficulty, but personally, the game provides just enough progressively growing difficulty to keep it interesting and fresh at the start of each new level. Whether it is the flashy visuals, the great movement system, or the continuous challenge, Thumper provides an enthralling experience to anyone who picks it up and who is also willing to start over a few times when they don't originally achieve an "S" score on a stage. New Game+, inbound.

I saw this game on a list of "Great Games You Missed in 2017!" I'm a long time fan of rhythm games, producer of electronic music, and fan of cosmic horror. How could I not love it? Turns out this is one of the rare times I've really regretted buying a game on steam.

First off, this is the most arrhythmic "rhythm game" I've ever played. How it calls itself a rhythm game I dont know. It's a Simon Says/QTE game and your actions **sometimes** create musical moments after you input them. You won't be using your ears to input commands, you will be using your eyes, which is awful since a lot of the prompts are not even visible. You can input commands wrong/skip commands entirely and not be punished at all, but then die to a wall not even visible until the second you need to respond to it. 

The music is 100% forgetable and at no point do you feel a part of it. As I think back on my time playing, I remember the same boring kick drum, same boring snare, and a seemingly random placed preset synth for over an hour. 

If you want the better version of this game, it was made over 15 years ago and is called REZ. It's on steam. Spend your money on that and not this.

I had to come post this as soon as I finished playing, because this game wowed me so much (though I should mention I this is more my initial impressions, since I only played about an hour). It's not often you see a game with such a unique premise as this, and even less often you see one so well executed. Everything is excellent, from the music to the visuals to the controls (even on keyboard). The music and visuals speak for themselves from the trailer, but I do really praise the controls. They feel so precise that when you inevitably mess up you have no one to blame but yourself. The difficulty curve too, is perfect. It starts you off slowly, and as soon as I found myself thinking, "I feel like I could take on a bit more," there it was. So far nothing has felt bullshit either, everything has been very fair and when I mess up it's my fault.

The only nitpicks I have are: 
1. It took me much to long to figure out how to recenter my headset
2. The synth-y non percussive elements of the music could be a bit louder, I sometimes have to focus to hear them and you can't afford extra focus in this game
3. The first two bosses look nearly identical. Maybe it's just the first two but it would be disappointing if such an excellent visual style was wasted on only a weird tiki head looking dude.

So, I see this game and take a quick peek then pass it by.

I mention it to a buddy and try to explain it to him.

"Yeah, it's this freaky game where you're a beetle of some sort and you do something with music, but I can't figure out how it's actually played."

"Oh, THUMPER!", he says. "Yeah, it's freaking awesome. Just get it."

So, I did. And he was right. Such a simplistic game in theory, right? You press one button and move the stick to music, shapes, and colors. But it's so much more than that.

It's a fast-paced, musical, test-your-reflexes game that will keep you playing. And playing.

Just take the advice I took. Get it. You will not be disappointed.

38475459.review:
[b]Thumper[/b] has a subline, dreamy design focus where the artwork, music, sound effects & streamlined gameplay combine to set the tone, altering your perceptions of reality. It's trance-inducing, beautiful & strange, but the void is full of surprises.

[b]Be one with the Space Beetle[/b]; it all starts out calm, introducing you to the basic control scheme through the first set of stages & how to combine them, but your peaceful existence quickly ramps up. Before you know it, it's a hardcore, ludicrously fast challenge of your reflexes. As with other rhythm based games, the longer you go without mistakes the higher your score will become. Mistakes don't often spell the end of the run, but too many in sequence & the [b]Space Beetle[/b] will not be happy.

All the controls are boiled down to a single button & directional input combinations. Although simple, it did feel a little counter-intuitive for me, taking a short while to get a grip on the timings & position of the hit zones. Using both press & hold actions for the button adds some complexity as you transition between flying above or gliding on the track. Whichever move you make, they all have a great tactile response. Grinds feel heavy, jumps hit the ground with the impact of a super hero & glides through the air have that light touch.

[b]Pure Rhythm?[/b] There are sections very precise with the rhythm timings but as it speeds up & the adrenaline pumps it loses some cohesion. Relying on the rhythm for your action timing can become problematic in later stages & throw you out. The music adds a massive amount to the experience, but does veer away from being more pure rhythm based gameplay as it gets harder. Outside of the alignment to the music, the levels are well designed and generally flow well.

Although I enjoy a challenge, the main drawback with [b]Thumper[/b]  [i](for me)[/i] is the overall difficulty level increased too quickly. It goes from very easy to crazy fast in just a few levels, which limits the level variation you can access without pushing through. If you are a mere mortal & get stuck like I did a lot [i](& still am!)[/i], then the repetition of the levels may discourage frequent replays & just lead to abandonment. I still like to come back and play as it is truly a great game, but wish a "Play[b]-[/b]" mode was added for those less rhymically inclined like myself to at least experience the full game. For the price, it’s a little light on the content; more levels or random mode would also be welcomed.

Most aptly titled, [b]Thumper[/b]  certainly lives up to its name. Thumpin' audio & visuals & Thumpin' physics & controls, it’s a one-of-a-kind experience that will melt your synapses!


[url=http://store.steampowered.com/curator/6857016/]If you enjoyed reading this review, please follow [u]True Blue Reviews[/u] for more recommendations![/url]

Thumper is awesome and beautiful. The tension is structured so well that although it is frustrating, I forgive the game in minutes while playing it. I went through levels 1 to 3 on keyboard and went for S rank. Succeeded through determination. When I tried level 4 I could not keep that up at any sublevel/part of level 4 (read checkpoint). I got through those hard and awe inspiring levels this way but the final boss was so hard I had to beat him with a traditional controller. 
Staying adapted to the switching of lanes was possible because of it.

If there are any professionals out there that can finish this game without a controller I would like to see them try. Just don't wreck your keyboard. Thumper looks unique and the only rhythm game that stood out to me enough to buy, but don't risk breaking your keyboard over it. 

This requires a traditional controller to keep going for a longer time at your best skill. The only game I have that requires that controller to a greater degree is Attack on Titan: Wings of Freedom.

Also, the certainty of having a failed turn when you could have sworn you had that perfect turn is a reccuring event akin to and more common than the "can't place that there milord"s of a stronghold game. It just doesn't have the same memeable ring to it.  But the almost explosion like movements going on when you take damage (just what flies of of your beetle, it doesn't affect your control) looks amazing. The death explosion looks incredible too.

Frustration, beauty and sound come together to lure you into and pull you out of gaming. It also gives a pretty consistent adrenaline rush. I don't know how to compare it to another game and that is why I nominated Thumper for defying discription.

37849670.review:
Thumper is a very zen-like game with a great soundtrack and visuals that lull you into a very "chill" space as you play, though still demands fast reflexes to do well. 

You speed along a track with various turns and obsticals which you must navigate either by steering appropriately or hitting an action button to speed up, jump or other actions. All these are timed with the game's electronica soundtrack (making it much in the vein of Rez or Frequency/Amplitude).  The game can be difficult - most stages only give you one allowed mistake and you're forced to repeat it. The stages don't change in terms of layout, so mastering some requires learning the track's actions. Along the way there are opportunities for grabbing bonus elements that can restore that one mistaken if you get several, but some require very careful timing.

It also has creative boss battles that use the same type of collection aspect to launch attacks against the boss. 

The whole game is minimalist in instruction, so there is some learn-as-you-go elements, but the stages and checkpoints are frequent enough to not be frustrating.

This is the perfect type of game to slip on some headphones and play through when you just need to relax, since it readily immerses you into the sights and sounds of the game. It's not necessarily a groundbreaking title, but production-wise it is excellently done.

37578503.review:
I played Rez on the Dreamcast in 2001. Then again, later, with the PS2 and 360 rereleases, and again this year with the Steam release. I largely consider the game incomparable, with nothing else I've played since quite matching its style, but if there ever were an heir to Rez's legacy, it would be Thumper. 
Rez came out 16 years ago and still feels futuristic, in a distinctly zen-cyberpunk sort of way. Thumper, though barely a year old, carves out a similarly fresh niche with its unsettlingly organic surreal-futurist hellscape. More than anything else, Thumper feels intense. Thumper makes your palms sweat and your heart race. At once mercilessly unforgiving in its execution and yet completely fair in its rules, Thumper teaches you everything you need to know and then expects that you will learn and understand. Thumper throws a tremendous amount of light and noise and motion and discordancy and trusts that you will sort out the information that you need from all of the madness and push through the maelstrom it sends your way. 
And then there's the last level. Christ, the last level. It may be brutal but it's worth the entire effort of the rest of the game to see how the last level subverts all the rules you've learnt up to that point. 
If you enjoy the merest concept of a rhythm game that effects an actual physical response from the player, play Thumper. Just don't play it on a keyboard unless you've got a decent orthopedic surgeon.

37365571.review:
First of all, I'm an enormous fan of music and rhythm games, and if they're available for Steam, I have probably played them.  Everyone's tastes differ, obviously, but I'd like to say I know what I'm talking about!

This is probably my most favourite rhythm game of all time - for the super-satisfying, visceral, heart-pounding experience, for the exciting but fair challenge, for its crazy abstract aesthetic, but also for being a really excellent GAME.  EVERYTHING about it is good - the visuals, the controls, the challenge, the soundtrack, the game design.  More on that later...

*****************************
WILL I LIKE THUMPER??

- If you enjoy rhythm or music games, Thumper may be for you.
- If you enjoy feeling a fast-paced, highly visceral connection to what you're playing, Thumper may be for you.
- If you enjoy psychedelic imagery and abstract, transcendant experiences, Thumper may be for you.
- Check out gameplay videos of Thumper on YouTube - does it excite you, or give you ASMR-like satisfaction just from watching it?  Thumper may be for you.

It did all of these things for me.  I was dying to love Thumper, but will I ACTUALLY like it??

As far as I can tell, people who wanted to like it, but didn't enjoy Thumper mostly have a problem with the fast-paced nature of the game - they claim it requires memorization or unreasonably fast reflexes.  I **strongly** disagree.  I had this problem with the game Cosmophony - the final level required careful memorization and practice, and could only be done through painfully learning the sneaky parts that WILL kill you the first time.  I like hard games - challenge isn't the issue - but having to memorize passages defeats the purpose of music games for me - I want to respond and react to the sounds as they happen, not be concerning myself memorizing button sequences.

Easy solution!  Watch a YouTube video of the final level of Thumper, Level 9.  Notice you can hear audio cues ahead of time for each obstacle, as well as clearly see where obstacles appear further down the track most of the time.  This is as hard as the game gets.  If you're interested in Thumper, and it seems reasonably doable to you, GET THE GAME.  ITS SO GOOD.

There's also another portion of "didn't like Thumper" because they didn't like the soundtrack.  Again, just watch a bit of it, and decide for yourself if that's something you can get into.

*****************************

Thumper is an **excellent** game with a carefully constructed difficulty curve.  There are tricky passages of course, but you have the equivalent of two hit points, and if you lose any, you have the ability to gain them back with skill.  There are also regular checkpoints, so you never have to grind levels from the beginning.  The controls are beautifully simple and approachable - Left Right Up Down X - and yet you'll find there's a lot you can do with those basic buttons if you really want to get into it.

Ultimately, it's fairly simple to learn the basics and sail through the levels and simply survive, but there is a ton of room for precision and expertise - if you want to up your challenge, you don't even need to try different play modes.  Thumper lets you make it harder on yourself just by attempting trickier moves.  For example, don't just survive the corners - perfect them for stacking bonuses!  But if you mess up the timing, you might die.  Do you just get by, or do you risk going for the bonuses?  

The better you get at the game, the more challenge it has to offer, and is extremely satisfying to "get right."  I can't recommend this game enough.  My ONLY warning is some people have problems "seeing" the track ahead of time - just check it out on YouTube first!

Oh, and a note on controllers: YOU DON'T NEED A CONTROLLER.  The visceral feedback from controller vibration is awesome and super satisfying, but I actually find keyboard to be a much better for this game.  You need accuracy and precision if you really want to master the game, and I find the millimeter I need to twich my finger faster and easier than having to roll my thumb around on a D-pad or joystick.  Or maybe I just have tiny thumbs.  Whatever.  Point is, controllers not required.

Please support this game.  Aside from it being an awesome game, I had some technical difficulties and lost my game file due to an unrelated computer problem - the developer promptly addressed my problems and sent me a replacement file so I didn't lose any progress.  They seem awesome.  Just buy it!

36859368.review:
This is a pretty dang good game. I find it challenging and addictive, its particularly hard if you're trying for perfect S scores like me. So far I've gotten a bit into level 5 and sometimes I question my willpower on getting the S rank. I've had to take a break but I will be giving it another shot real soon. I will get every acheivement!
That said, if you're not into self-inflicted mental torture it's still good. A lot of it is memorizing patterns rather than pressing buttons to the beat, but even then it's real satisfying when you thump and slide to the drums. The music is great and you will feel it in your core, especially when you die. 
Some cons I find in the game is that sometimes it feels off, like to not miss the "thumps" I find myself having to press the button a bit before the beat, which is slightly annoying but eventually you kind of get use to it and its not as bad. I found this mostly a problem in level 1-2 when it's slower and not as complex. 
There's also been times when the track waves quite a bit (like during boss fights and special moves) and it waves so much that it hurts the beetle. This did get annoying, particularly on difficult levels that I had to do over and over again. I would finally make progress and this wave that acts like a turn hurts me and ruins the score. Perhaps this wouldn't be so bad if it was consistent but sometimes it doesn't happen. I'm not even sure if you can turn as there is practically no warning.
Overall I found this game worth the money. If you like rythm games this is the game for you, and if you want a challenge go for S ranks, if not, then don't. I'd probably would have finished the game by now if I wasn't going for perfect ranks. Previosuly I gotten half way through level 4 in two or three hours.

I really loved this at the beginning, then it kept dragging out without new mechanics and totally similar levels for so long that i dropped it multiple times.
The difficulty is the main weak point as you can simply "survive" the levels without too much effort except for bosses, the only challenge comes from scoring ranks S but it's really frustrating being mostly mnemonical and with some checkpoints being so far away.
It's not even a real rhythm game, as there rarely is any music to follow, you ARE the beat yourself with a lot of cool repeating patterns and buildups, but this makes you rely on visual clues that can be pretty hard to spot with the oversaturated graphics.
That being said the gameplay is fresh, and it looks and plays perfectly. I'm really torn on this one.

+ Tight controls and fresh gameplay
+ Trippy aesthetics
+ Groovy soundtrack
+ Perfect 21:9 support
+ VR support

- Really overstays its welcome with 9 world that all look and play the same
- Rhythm is often hard to follow, visual clues are unconsistent
- Difficulty mostly comes from trying to get high scores

3/5

It starts very easy, teaching you the basics of how to play, and then takes you on a full ride of skill. The musics (or rather the ambiances) are really good, the graphics are amazing (I love the GLOW), and the challenges get harder and harder after each level.

This is definitely one of my best purchases on Steam, and the absolute best VR experience I have tested so far.

10/10

35184214.review: Thumper is sustained tension and dread in rhythm game form, condensing the sense of being in an out-of-control vehicle and barely staying fully conscious into a small metal scarab flying down an interdimensional highway. It’s unfamiliar and troubling, but striking and hypnotic and hella fun. Onlookers will think you’re opening a portal to Cool Hell.

35176854.review:
[b]Release Date: October 11th, 2016
Developer: Drool
Publisher: Drool
[/b]

Thumper starts of rather casual but then takes a sudden turn and you might be left [i]Drool[/i]ing.

Fairly simplistic gameplay and a rather unique style mixed with music you barely hear or rather pay attention to since you're more than busy not missing a single beat. Not to mention all dem flashy lights ... My god so many light effects ...

I feel like the name of the dev/publisher is quite fitting: Drool. The game sure as shit makes you drool at one point either out of pure concentration where you enter a I want to say state of trance by simply playing the game and going for an [b]S[/b] rank or 'cause you're sensitive to all the effects that are going on and stuff.

Remember all those lil' notifications in other games which tell you to play in a well lit room and to take breaks every now and then? You did all those things in those games? Yeah me neither. In Thumper though ... I strongly recommend it.

At one point it felt like [url=https://www.wikiwand.com/en/Sensory_overload]sensory overload[/url] ... It just became too much for me. Now keep in mind I shoot for a S rank in every level/world and I restart as soon as I miss something ... Now doing that at 22pm or 2am ... yeah not such a good idea.

Anyhoo let's get into it.
http://steamcommunity.com/sharedfiles/filedetails/?id=1136242895
Thumper does a fairly good job by providing a simplistic tutorial and it teaches you nothing more than what you need at the moment. Basically it goes like this: Hit A when there's a field on the ground. Hold A for those vertical thingies, hold A and tilt the left stick in order to turn, tilt up and hold A in order to fly and so on. Nothing more.

Now the first few levels and even worlds ... I consider world 1-3 tutorial worlds since things get faster and more hectic in world 4 in my eyes.

Anyway you get points for everything.

There're 9 worlds in Thumper and each consisiting of different amount of levels. Now you can just rush through the game and not caring 'bout your rank as long as you manage to stay alive. I'd say that's the best experience. Being able to experience the game or rather each world in one sitting would be the best course of action since the levels seamlessly transition and if you do care 'bout your rank or if you just wanna take a break then fear not my friend. There's a checkpoint at the end of every level which you have to hit in order to activate. So there's that.

From what I've seen so far, I'm on world 4 level 27 as I'm writing this, there're two bosses in every world which you have to beat. One is a mini-boss and the other is the big ol' meanie.
http://steamcommunity.com/sharedfiles/filedetails/?id=1136242832 
Now how does one actually beat or rather kill stuff in Thumper? By the magic of those green glowish tiles. You'll know which I mean once you see'em and there's even a small tutorial for those as well so it's all gonna be good lil' Timmy.

Now let's get to a crucial part: The OST.

I'm not gonna say it's bad or anything but it's fairly generic and all of the tracks kind of sound the same but then again I'm barely paying any attention to it while playing. The OST was made for that game with it's goal in mind; being a rhythm-action game.

Here's just my two cents. I've played Osu! before and I would consider that a rhythm game but Thumper? Yeah dunno about that. To me it's more of a test-your-reflexes-kind-of-thing-while-your-eyes-are-melting. Guess that sums it up quite nicely.

There's even a New Game+ which I haven't touched yet but I'm guessing that it's just the same old shit just way harder and more flashy.

If you're like me and dig arcade games and stuff then go ahead and pick up Thumper.

I'm not able to play the VR version of the game but I'm guessing two things would happen: I'd either go completely insane and the game would be hella dope.

People been going on 'bout the psychedelic-mumbo-jumbo but meh. I'm not a 420blazeit Kiddo so that shit don't matter to me.
http://steamcommunity.com/sharedfiles/filedetails/?id=1144834607
What matters is this: Solid gameplay. Nice visuals. Music is okayish and the game's well worth your money.
Full price or on sale.

35146252.review:
Thumper es un juego rítmico que se desarrolla en una pesadilla psicodélica. Manejamos a un escarabajo que se desplaza a toda velocidad por una vía infinita en el hiperespacio y debe sortear obstáculos dispuestos según un ritmo musical infernal hasta enfrentarse, al final de cada nivel, a una cabeza alienígena demoníaca gigante. Es tan alucinante como suena.

El juego tiene un control sencillísimo, podría manejarse literalmente con un mando de una consola antigua de Atari: necesitamos un stick de control (recomiendo pararse en las opciones para ajustar un poco la sensibilidad de la palanca) y un botón de acción. A medida que nuestro escarabajo se desplaza por los raíles, aparecerán unos indicadores luminosos siguiendo el ritmo de la música: si presionamos el botón de acción cuando estemos encima de ellos, aumentaremos nuestra puntuación al final del segmento del nivel, y si encadenamos varios indicadores lograremos cadenas de combos que aumentarán aún más esta puntuación. Estas cadenas de combos, por cierto, son la única manera que tendremos de derrotar a los jefes: tenemos que "clavar" cuatro secciones para lanzar cuatro disparos al enemigo y derrotarlo, sin fallos.

A medida que pasamos niveles se van añadiendo nuevos obstáculos que requerirán distintos movimientos, y aquí entra de nuevo el botón de acción: si lo presionamos, protegemos a nuestro escabajo, y esto es imprescindible para sortear las curvas, recodos y trampas del escenario. Pero no podemos mantener presionado todo el rato el botón: primero porque sino jamás lograremos cadenas de combos, y segundo porque mientras estemos protegidos el escabajo estará fijado en uno de los raíles (y por tanto, en el momento en que haya más de uno en pantalla tendremos un problema). También podemos hacer que vuele el escarabajo moviendo el stick hacia arriba, y así podremos desplazarnos incluso estando protegidos manteniendo el botón de acción; y si movemos el stick hacia abajo para aterrizar justo cuando estemos encima de un indicador luminoso lanzaremos un disparo (imprescindible para eliminar unos escudos que aparecen a veces para proteger a los jefes).

Como vemos, el control se basa principalmente en moverse a los lados (y en determinados momentos arriba y abajo) con el stick manteniendo pulsado o no el botón de acción. Es muy sencillo, y sin embargo el juego está tan bien diseñado que constantemente despliega situaciones variadas y complejas. Es un juego muy difícil y exigente: no depende tanto de seguir el ritmo (aunque esto es imprescindible para alcanzar las mayores puntuaciones) como de tener buenos reflejos... y algo más que buenos reflejos en los tramos más traicioneros.

Yo no tengo gafas de RV, pero no las he necesitado para disfrutar del juego; si algún día las tengo será un incentivo para volver a jugarlo. Da igual cómo lo juguéis: es una experiencia audivisual terrorífica y alucinante. Hay que verlo para creerlo.

Totalmente recomendado.

35078817.review:
I normally don't really play rythm games, regardless of the music, I've never found myself to entralled by them. This one hooked me in when I first saw glimpses of gameplay. Perhaps it is due to my lack of experience in the genre, but this game feels like it does everything in it's power to have the gameplay/movement and visuals directly correlate to the music/beat. 

It starts off nice and easy to get you into the mood, then after a while it ramps up difficulty and chaos just enough to still be fun. The visuals are great and complement the music which can be hectic yet still have a sort of luring pattern to it. 

My only complaint is that in the later levels (I've only made it to level 4 btw), the music and beat become very sperratic and the gameplay turns into a constant test of reaction time more than following the beat (which may become drowned out by the sound effects in-game). 

Overall, it is a game that feels very satisfying when you play well. I recommend it to anyone who has the money to drop (and a controller, the added vibration makes it much more cathartic).

35043121.review:
Thumper was simply not for me. It felt very boring. I felt like the only thing the game required me to do was to press buttons to the tune of some boring music. The difficulty gradually increases as you complete the first few levels but price-wise (£16) it was not fun enough for me to continue playing or justify keeping the game in my collection. If the price was less than £5 I'd have probably given it a second chance. 

The VR support was lame because there was no roomscale or motion-controller support, but even if there was, I don't know how that would have made the game any better. Perhaps if I could sit in the cockpit of an actual Space beetle in VR mode and make it jump, turn, strafe, dive etc to the tune of the music using the motion controllers or the HMD then may be I could have probably justified the price. 

For both VR and non-VR you can get more interesting rhythm-based games for less than £10 (Polynomial 2, Soundboxing, Chroma Lab, etc).

Having said all that, if you are a big fan of rhythm-based music games and don't have VR, then buy it on sale if it ever goes below £5.

34778960.review:
I've been playing video games for 25+ years and Thumper might be my favorite ever. The way the game assaults your senses is both exhausting and immensely satisfying. My play sessions were usually not much longer than an hour because I started to have trouble focusing after a while due to the intensity. This also meant that I never felt bored or like I was grinding. The 30ish hours I played feel like much much longer due to that intensity.

My first casual playthrough was a great experience on it own. I encountered a difficulty spike somewhere in the middle and another one later on but eventually got past it. When I replayed for S-ranks I started to appreciate the game on a whole new level. On my first playthrough I was just focused on surviving, which was tense enough as it was at my skill-level. When playing for S-ranks you have to play near-perfectly and you have to learn a bunch of new techniques that you didn't need when playing casually. I really got to appreciate how the levels slowly teach you new concepts and then just keep building on them more and more. It was also funny how on my first playthrough the bosses were the most difficult, but with S-ranks it was the levels themselves and the bosses almost felt like a break where you could relax a bit.

I usually don't replay games and the reason I did for Thumper was because its actions were so satisfying to perform and the state of mind I had to be in. If I got too stressed or frustrated I would make too many mistakes and would be unable to proceed. I had to remain calm in the face of repeated failure and the sensory overload the game throws at you. Every time I tried to learn a bit more or improve my muscle memory. That calm combined with the amazing sound, visuals and speed has made it one of my best experiences in gaming.

Pros:

- Very good pacing overall. It has enough small breaks and it switches between long and short levels often. 
- Music based game done well, for the most part.
- Visually unique.
- Very responsive and intuitive controls.
- The first game that actually made me want to S-Rank clear every level. This never happens to me.
- Very nice overall atmosphere and "world" design.

Cons:

- Sometimes the rhythm is all over the place, as in: It changes too much sometimes.
- In some levels (especially the last ones) the visuals are over the top making it hard to see the jumping pads.
- Some later levels seem easier than earlier levels. This can just be me being weird though. Difficulty is a subjective term to an extend after all.


Overall score: 8.2/10

34694558.review:
As a player, I've got to give it to these guys for the stylistic game they have created. But as a designer, I can't recommend anyone I know to buy this game.

Simply because for all this game's uniqueness and beauty, it's pytrid when it comes to design choices.

Color schemes render level elements borderline invisible. I've been blindsided by so many quick turns on red levels that the game literally stopped being fun for me midway my playthrough and I don't see any reason to go back.

Secondly, the control scheme. The hardest bit of this game is the fact that you expect players to use from at least two to almost all four direction keys within a singular second. I know you want to appeal to the 'oh lol git gud' crowd of gamers, but with manufactured difficulty and faulty design, this game falls far beyond most other games with such an extremely punishing gameplay loop.

Secondly, the varying lengths between two stages. Fuck, sometimes I have to wait up to fifteen seconds for the next bit of gameplay to begin, and sometimes the next button press is mere milliseconds away from the last level's end. This is confusing, bad, and honestly absolute shite design. 

Moving on to level progression itself. I reached level 5 before the game began bodying me completely, and I consider myself a decent player. What's the point of making a game that 70% of the people playing will never be able to beat? Games like Dark souls - which have exceedingly tough gameplay - allow players to level up and get stronger in lower-levelled areas so that they have an edge if a boss or an area is too tough for this. This game, unlike those, has no comeback mechanics. And before one compares this to bullet hell games, one must also consider that BH games allow players to have upgrades that do the same. This game has none of those.

it's not all bad, though. The game is unique and the soundtrack and visuals are beyond stellar. There's a nice progression where you teach the player how to use every new mechanic that comes in, but the mishmash of mechanics the player is left with in the later stages is so confusing, it ends up getting the player killed over and over again. Quality, not quantity - something that your design seems to miss.

I can see the love that the devs have put into this game. I can see their soul in every level I did enjoy. But in the end, the beauty of the game is almost completely soiled by the mostly mediocre - some hinging on absolute garbage - mechanics.

The game's like the country of France. Beautiful place (visuals and sound), shame about the people (mechanics).

34015543.review:
Smal disclaimer: I haven't beaten the game, but I'm up to the 7th level of 9 and I feel like I can speak for the game's quality. Also, I got it on sale for 11 or 12$ and haven't played with VR.

If you like what you see in the trailers, then you'll probably like what Thumper has to offer.

Thumper's a rhythm game centered around just pressing button prompts in response to various threats and signals. There's barely a story to speak of and the most I've seen so far is a recurring boss that kind of changes with each level. I've seen Thumper constantly compared to rhythm games, but it's not really like any other rhythm game I've ever played. There are no standout tracks and rarely any moments where I find myself bobbing along the rhythm. Instead, Thumper just commands your attention with these heavy metallic drum noises that dictate almost all of the game's music, and instead of feeling like you're playing a song, it feels like the great music is more of a byproduct of you playing the game.

That's not a bad thing, though, because Thumper is a unique premise with excellent execution. It has all the simplicity of the Runner games with all the intensity of something like the new DOOM. Think of super simple gameplay with a very harsh atmosphere and brutal difficulty. And by brutal difficulty, I mean repeating whole sections over and over because you didn't pull off a sequence of button presses without making a mistake. This brings up one of my only problems with Thumper: the game is so hard at times, you're forced to memorize levels which leads to a trial-and-error sort of gameplay. I feel like this is a side effect of simply not being very good at the game and not paying attention to certain cues, but I can see it turning off some players. If you don't like repeating yourself like in Super Meat Boy, Runner, or 1001 Spikes, you might not love the game's later levels.

But if you DO like punishing gameplay and everything you see in the trailer, then I'd say Thumper is worth your time. Not only is the main campaign tough as nails, getting S rank on every level will def keep you occupied. And there's even a NG+ which basically adds permadeath to each level with no healing and makes you start from the beginning of the level if you quit. That may sound ridiculous, but I LOVE that it's a feature because it fits the hardcore nature of this game so well. And just to cover all bases, the game looks and sounds good, runs great, the controls feel tight, and the atmosphere is very unique. My only problems are the tougher bosses and the fact that, during long play sessions, you can get a little burnt out because the game CONSTANTLY demands your attention. I guess that's what happens when you play Breath of the Wild for 3 weeks and then move to something like this. LOL

I like Thumper.

33849210.review:
TL;DR : Game is beautiful, Runs well, fantastic rythmic early stages, non-existant rythm midgame-endgame, uses "cheap/bad" hardcore mechanics; game is based on sound and uses sound to throw you off later on and just becomes irritating (you're almost better off muting the game later on, but that defeats the purpose of this game right?
).
If I could do a mixed review I would. I'm only giving a thumbsdown to help personally balance the game from currently a very positive to either Mostly Positive or at most Mixed.

     The game presents itself as a psychedelic hardcore rhythm game. It certainly is beautiful and very engaging to the eye, but it doesn't feel like any rhythm game at all. Each stage has it's own kind of beat and feel to the rhythm, so each stage does feel unique; but personally only the first 3ish stages had rhythms that I could predict/feel. After the first few stages the beat doesn't seem... "there". 

      The first 3 stages I can tap my foot to and almost predict what is going to come up next and how it'll sound; it's generally pleasing to my ears. The next 4 stages I got to feels like there's no beat, and takes a kind of "dubstep" feel to how the notes are placed, I can't for the love of me find a beat to tap/nod to, doesn't feel satisfying once you hit all the notes and "complete" the song, and doesn't actually sound like anything but random instruments/pots&pans banging about; every note comes as a suprise to me and I end up playing the game not by following the rythm, but by trial and error and just memorizing the placement of objects (no rythm needed). 

     There's a slight neutral nitpick and that's the preemptive sound for each note. In the background you'll hear a note play to what's about to come up, and you kind of gauge when to hit that note; In the first few stages this is used along with the sound of you hitting the notes to make a nice beat/song to play along to. Later on the game gets faster paced and has more notes to hit, so it comes to a point where you just hear background notes overlapping and obstructing what beats you're hitting and just generally ruining the "song" that the game is trying to get you to make.

     One finally nitpick is turns. For the life of me some turns feel like they're programmed differently than others. You hold Actionbutton ([A] on controller) then left/right for what direction you're turning. You can also wait til the exact moment to actually hit the turn button for extra points and a nice "ping" sound that makes the song sound better. Some turns feel like their exact moment to hit the turn perfectly is placed differently than others. 90% of the turns seem to have a general rule on when to exactly hit the turn, and some feel like they're way sooner than before, making me take damage and costing me a retry or death. This can get very infuriating later game when all the sounds of preemptive notes and notes you're hitting overlap adding to the bad design type of difficulty; making it feel like the game isn't a skill-based hardcore where I can learn from mistakes, but rather a game that changes core rules randomly to make you hit a small bump to artificially impede progress.

     I want to like this game, but the only thing I can like about it is the sound (when they work), and the beautiful graphics; with that it is less of a game and more of something just to watch someone play than to play yourself. (5/10)
If I was to grade the game soley on the first 3 stages and the rest of the stages were made like the first 3, I would easily give a 9/10 or a 10/10 if the turns were more consitent.

33780636.review: Pretty cool game. The only thing that I would like to suggest is not make the game slow down so much if you mess up the first time. Although I prefer to get no-miss runthroughs, I like to see how far I can get when "sightreading" and slowing the game for me to miss half a beat will definitely end my run. I probably wouldn't recommend this game to casual rhythm game players, and I don't mean that in a bad way. If you're expecting to listen to the music and coast through the levels, then you're probably not going to have fun. The beat is pretty hard to keep track of, and I found myself attempting to tap my foot in time and failing at certain sections. There were times in the track where I had to basically guess where the beat was and go from there. Speaking of the track, there isn't much to listen to. There's barely any lyrical sections of the music within the tribal drums. I would say that this game is close to something like being in a drumline or auxillary-only percussion ensemble. It's a lot of call and response in which the call inputs get so convoluted that you have to depend on reactions and muscle memory. In all, I would say that this is a great game - the whole "story" of the game is pretty vague, but I'll let that slide since this is primarily a rhythm game after all. The graphics get kinda weird, but I guess they wanted to make this a horror game. I found myself really apreciating the different cadences the developers used, so thumbs up for that. Thanks for the great game!

33712869.review:
[u]Disclaimer: [/u] This review is considerably lengthy. The abridged version is: [b]buy it[/b]. I have been obsessed with this game for the past few days and that train, much like the space beetle you play as, is not stopping anytime soon. If you’re interested in reading about how I believe Thumper applies play conditioning, minimalism and cosmic horror to create a brilliant game filled with gorgeous graphics, an intense score and absurd replay value – go ahead!
 
This strange game is an incredibly satisfying trifecta of psychedelic art, rhythm-based play and horror tension. Seriously, somehow developers Drool have managed to make a game described as, [i]a space beetle travelling through the void[/i], a uniquely terrifying and intense experience. I want to focus the majority of my review on a concept I think Thumper executes brilliantly. It’s a term known as [b]play conditioning[/b], and it’s not mine – I first heard its use by film and games essayist [b]Hbomberguy[/b]. He coined the term vis-à-vis Thumper; so, with this in mind, I believe it to be intellectually honest for me to present his argument given that I will proceed to apply, expand and comment on it.

[b]Hbomberguy[/b] argues that Thumper is a difficult and unforgiving game. As a space beetle, you are constantly speeding through a nightmarish void filled with traps, aggressive abstract geometry and horrific giant heads. It’s like a racing game – only you’re a beetle with two lives and you will relentlessly respawn at the beginning of each level because in this game, the dead shall rise again until you escape hell. It’s a fast-paced adventure that requires great reaction time in a psychedelic environment that constantly assaults your senses. Nevertheless, Thumper is made in such a way that the more you play it the more intuitive the controls become. Your actions match the score in the background and, if done well, sync and contrast with the environment around you in such a way that it feels [i]good[/i] to pass a course with an S ranking. 

From a technical standpoint, [b]play conditioning[/b] is where, why and how should buttons reflect in-game actions. Thumper achieves such that with the help of mechanical minimalism the player is conditioned to play a fast, aggressive, relentless and intuitive game -- or so at least it is designed. Your controls are simple, WASD and SPACE BAR, but the combinations of moves and trap responses are almost infinite. Yet, throughout all that, your hand is comfortably numb, clicking away up to five keys to safely speed through a course in a truly melodic way. By the end of a course, the overall sync of action, score, color and learning curve resemble the moment when a guitarist learns a new song. That has been my experience – I have been obsessed with this game. It has tapped into my completionist vein and I will relentlessly redo a course until I get the highest mark. [b]Why?[/b] Because of this game’s incredible application of [b]play conditioning[/b]. The way the game mechanics are built promotes a type of gameplay that is challenging, rewarding, and ultimately, highly enjoyable. I have more fun failing a course over and over again, with each new time learning the course's inner mechanics like a new song, until I finally complete it with the highest mark than simply breezing through each score, ignoring certain optional obstacles, losing lives and achieving C, B or A marks.

Thumper also has an actual effective training method to introduce you to what we’ll call “the level’s learning curve”. At the beginning of each level, the first few courses focus on showing you a particular new skill or combination of actions – usually with a HUD display that will indicate exactly when to do what. Moreover, as the level progresses it incorporates learned skills, with current skills and the occasional unreferenced unlearned skill. It’s a way of avoiding monotony, increase replay value and keeping an element of surprise during each level (which has approximately twenty courses). All in all – great game, gorgeous graphics, intense score, beautiful mechanics and arguably one of the most recent games where mood, theme and immersion have nothing to do with story or characters.

[h1]If you enjoy the way I review games, join and follow my curator group! It comes with a fun discord channel for horror fans to chill and game. [url=http://steamcommunity.com/groups/malkavianmadness]Malkavian Madness[/url][/h1]

I have just finished the second "Level" in the game. 

I am a beetle endlessly screaming along a track to oblivion, dodging horrors along the way.

This game frustrates me to no end, and yet I keep playing just to get a little bit further along and receive even more punishing sequences that I fail, and fail again.

The music can best be described as punishing, a cacophony akin to listening to an airplane drone along while a toddler bangs pots and pans in time to the game action.

This is the most brilliant subversion of a rhythm game that I've ever played.

33672555.review:
Thumper’s brutal, breakneck speed and precision-based musical action kept me entranced for all nine of its bizarre, nightmarish stages, which contained enough nuanced high score-chasing tricks to demand several replays already. To really master Thumper’s many layers of rhythm-based mechanisms would take much more time than the 10 or so hours it takes to complete the first time – and that’s a challenge that I eagerly accept.

Menacing boss fights that manage to stay interesting despite a relatively linear structure and a strange, chrome-plated brand of cosmic horror that’s as fascinating as it is frightening make repeat trips easy and exciting. But it’s the music and sounds of Thumper that will stick with me the most, beckoning me back to that terrifying abyss for several more hours to come. 5/5

33658742.review:
First off, this is an excellent game. I've played through all of Play and three stages of Play+, and my initial feelings of awe and excitement have not dwindled. The issues I have with this game are so few that I have to list them specifically to fill out my cons side.

Graphics: 

Pros:
While I don't play on VR, the game itself is not demanding. With a GTX 1070, I've pushed 8x MSAA with 4K rendering at 144hz, and I haven't seen a frame dropped yet. Aesthetics, as others have mentioned, are very trippy. Bright lights and flashing objects fill the screen in a compact pleasing manner. I find this to be one of the key parts of the game, offering powerful imagery. 

Con:
At some instances, mainly the last stage in Play+, the visuals get so intense and saturated that it becomes nearly impossible to see. 

Audio: 

Pros:
For me, the music is a standout from other rhythm games. Where most other games will hardly ever tour away from straight 4/4 rhythm, this game has no qualms in handing out the grungiest offtime, polyrhythmic, additive timing beats. It's a refreshing breath of air, and I wish other reviewers understood the timing was on purpose. The mixing of the soundtrack gives it enourmous space, strengthening the games aesthetics. 

Cons:
Without a good audio setup the drums can get washed out in the reverberations and game's hits, making it difficult to play ontime. The snakes in the game appear with a high hissing sound, when they appear multiple at a time, any speaker set with a high frequency range can hurt your ears from the intensity. I recommend gamers play two decibals down from their max listening volume, to save on ear coverage.

Gameplay: 

Pros:
The gameplay is tight and responsive, and hitting notes are very satisfying, The game's difficulty curve is very smooth, except for stage 7 which I found the most difficulty in beating. The general opinion differs from stage to stage though, so I feel that it's a personal issue. General movements across the menus is fluid and fast. 

Cons:
Sometimes the stages can feel a bit repetitive. My biggest qualm comes from turns. Getting perfect timings on them can be frustrating because it's so unforgiving for pressing late. I've raged more than a few times repeatedly dying to turns that I feel I've hit properly.

My rating: 8.5/10

As everyone knows the game looks badass as fuck so here's my comment on something else.

Concidering the games aesthetic I was pleasently supprised about how easy it was to get into, the learning curve is actually pretty pleasant. At the start of each level you're introduced to the perils that lie before you in the abyss, and slowly eased into the level itself. 
Well.. that's up until level 5, when that piece of shit lazer cockring starts blasting your ass like the death star, while kicking you off beat with it's skrillex soundboard. God I hate that thing. But after a blood sacrifice and some really hard headbanging I managed to become one with Satan's bongobeats and, while jumping around in my couch like a disgruntled teen on a cybergoth concert, kicked level 5's ass into oblivion.

The music, which usually is the main focus in rythm based games, is suprisingly lacking in this one. The tracks aren't bad in any sense, don't get me wrong. But concidering that the visuals of the game really just punch you right in the tit with their fantastic sci-fi interpretation of Dante's Inferno, I'm very suprised that the music lacks the same kick. In comparison it at times feels, flat, monotone and quiet. That's of course understandable in the "pause" parts of each level, but when the action's on I'm really missing some hard clear rythm. I would really expect more bass and robotic rape noises. Go search up the noices the reapers in mass effect make, that's the kind of sound I was looking for with this music. In really intense parts of the game this problem kinda disapears because the sounds from all the obstacles you're smashing through just becomes a nice rhytmical beat in and of itself. The background music is just a bit pale when compared to the visuals is my point. 

For serious though I truly am enjoying this game, even though the learningcurve breaks after level 4 and that the music isn't as heavy as I'd like I would still recommend it to anyone that thinks Dark Souls isn't pissing them off enough, cause boy is this shit unfair at times. 

7/10 highly enjoyable and frustrating, will play it more

Thumper is a rhymthm game similar to Bit.Trip Runner: press buttons quickly and with precise timing to clear a series of stages. The music, sound effects, and visuals all give cues to when buttons should get pressed. The difficulty ramps up quickly and the game takes practice to beat.

The main innovations are in the atmosphere and the well-designed (though not well-explained) scoring system. High scoring requires a mix of excellent timing and good routing.

33542503.review:
Most rhythm games tend to be fairly bright and friendly, often leveraging colorful and relatively simple designs. The action might get a little frantic at times but the games in this genre usually aren’t actively trying to induce heart attacks in their players.

And then there’s Thumper, a nightmarish rollercoaster through a psychedelic hellscape. This game hates you and it isn’t trying to hide it. The graphics are steeped in bloody reds, the action crunches and screeches violently, and the music radiates intensity as you race headlong into sudden doom.

Gameplay uses up/down/left/right movement plus a single button which can be tapped or held for a few different effects in various situations. Each level ramps up the difficulty through several rounds and then hits you with a couple of malevolent bosses towering over increasingly fiendish tracks. It isn’t overly complicated but it’s plenty challenging.

Everything looks and sounds amazing, and the game has a pretty cool feel once you get the hang of it. Just be prepared for an experience that combines all the best qualities of a car accident and a heart attack.

33532683.review:
TL;DR: Buy this game.  Period.  It's one of the best of it's genre as of now.  10/10.  Also now giving it the 2017 "Mom's Spaghetti" award.

I originally found out about this game via The Beetles Of The People a.k.a. Jim Sterling.
I just had to have this game!
If the difficulty dissuades you, fear not!  It actually starts out fairly gentle and progressively gets more intense as you ride along.

Thumper is Audiosurf meets... anything dark and space-themed.
(The dark side(s) of Star Trek/Star Wars immediately come to mind...or perhaps Batman...)
I once read that the beetle in this game was inspired by some album art.

Good music, stellar sound design and cues, sleek and shiny visuals, responsive performance... what's not to like?

And finally, in case hemiola and odd rhythms (syncopation) aren't enough for you, this game has odd time signatures as well.  Think about it: isn't 4/4 a bit overused in this day and age?  Playing in 5/4 and 7/4 is so refreshing (but 5/8 and 7/8 are so challenging!).

33527289.review:
一款非常熱血的節奏遊戲, 看似音樂戰機但也不完全一樣, 酷炫華麗的畫面與音效為讓熱血更上一階!
對節奏感有獨特情感的你一定會愛上!

玩家是一隻太空甲蟲, 在虛空中的一條似乎沒有盡頭的軌道上疾速前進, 消滅路上遇到的奇怪生物與巨頭

!!!這是節奏遊戲, 不是音樂遊戲!!!

●評分
- 畫面: 8/10 大量閃瞎眼的華麗特效, 圖形表面很有質感.
- 音樂: 5/10 這裡指的是BGM, 也就是遊戲中協助玩家伴奏的一些打擊樂器等等的音效. 雖然沒有特別好聽或印象深刻, 但是在伴奏上對玩家來說是不可或缺且非常大的幫助.
- 音效: 9/10 這裡指的是譜面音效. 非常棒! 雖然不是給10分但是也說不出哪裡不好 哪裏該改善. 很有感覺很恰當, 不會有感覺奇怪的音效. 幾個音效組成各式各樣的節奏, 遊戲的核心所在.
- 劇情: 3/10 除了Steam頁面上的解說, 遊戲中沒有任何對話 字幕或是旁白. 但是完全不影響遊戲體驗, 這不是劇情遊戲.
- 娛樂性: 7/10 喜愛節奏遊戲的玩家一定會非常喜歡.
- 耐玩性: 6/10 普通, 除了第一周目玩通關, 之後也都只是挑戰更高分或是玩加速模式, 加速模式譜面和一般模式一模一樣.

●優點
- 簡單的指令, 好聽有特色的譜面(節奏)組合, 遊戲的主核心.
- 漂亮有質感的畫面, 遊戲的第二個核心所在.
- 音效很有質感 很有feel

●缺點
- 其實從頭到尾遊戲畫面看起來基本上都一模一樣.
- 整體音效與音樂不會讓人留下深刻印象. (但是在遊玩過程中卻是重點所在)
- 畫面特效太過華麗, 而特定部分場景顏色太過相近, 或是軌道彎曲的弧度, 有時很難但見譜面. 甚至後面的關卡不是難在譜面.

以上優缺點似乎有點矛盾. 我想表達的是, 這遊戲好不好取決於你對 節奏 的感覺.
如果你對節奏感有獨特情感, 簡單3 4樣的敲擊聲對你說都能構成節奏的話你會認為這遊戲非常棒, 音效與畫面種類不多, 但是節奏組合從頭到尾每關都不一樣. 但是有個重點是在於你有感覺到那個節奏.
如果你對節奏感沒有很多的感覺在, 而且比較偏向追求新鮮感和爆點的話, 你會認為這遊戲很單調, 基本上玩完第一關就可以不用玩了, 因為後面對你來說只是增加難度而已.


另外, 全成就要的話第一周目就可以完成, 只是要不斷重試直到完美. 個人第一周目的通關與第二周目的全成就花了約26小時.
雖然個人非常愛這遊戲, 但是建議還是等到特價約270左右再買. 這遊戲賣的是節奏 特效與音效.

33406803.review:
Thumper is the most fitting title for this game, as is its caption as "A Rhythm Violence Game".

It's a game made by two very angry men. It features a beatle on a rail ramming itself into walls and  shit, 'fighting' giant polyhedral tentacle shapes and a big Day-of-the-Dead-meets-punk-rock skull. I say 'fighting', because as far as I know the 'notes' are actually enemies and/or attacks. I don't know nor care. It's glorious.
The gameplay is enormously satisfying, every hit 'note' and wall grind punching a beat right into your ears, every missed 'note' breaking a window instead. The rhythms are complex, the soundtrack so utterly heavy and percussive. It's like an angst-filled teen with a drumkit and some talent. 
Some gameplay elements (e.g. how to hit certain 'notes') are either not explained in too much detail, or I was too busy pummeling my hands into the soundtrack. I bought the game alone first off, and bought the soundtrack later, if that's any indication of how satisfying the beats are.

Definitely play it with a controller though.

I think the best rhythm games can almost be played with your eyes closed, and this one falls a bit short of the mark -- especially once you get to the off-beat stuff past level 3. Still, this game is great fun and a must-play for fans of the rhythm genre!

33080662.review:
Thumper presents itself as a rhythm game, but gets so much of the design behind rhythm games wrong that I cannot in good conscious recommend it to fans of the genre. There are plenty of other rhythm games that I'd recommend over Thumper. I list some of them in the sections below.

[h1]Music Selection[/h1]

Let's start with the music: It's droning percussion without a lot of variation or movement. Find a youtube video of someone playing Thumper. If you like what you hear, then great, maybe this game is for you. If you don't like what you hear, bad news: that's basically all you're going to be hearing the whole game. Most rhythm games have a selection of songs that you can play at your leisure; if there's a song you don't like, no big deal: just don't pick that song, and instead pick the songs you [i]do[/i] like. Unfortunately Thumper is structured as a linear game where you play the levels in order, one after the other. And you can't play level N until you've beaten level N-1.

[b]Games that did it better:[/b] The Bemani series (Dance Dance Revolution, Beatmania/IIDX, Guitar Freaks, DrumMania, etc.), Rock Band, Guitar Hero, etc. all have varied song lists in different genres and style, and let you pick which songs you want to play.

[h1]Graphics/Aesthetics[/h1]

This is arguably Thumper's strongest selling point, but graphics are only enjoyable insofar that you get to see them. And to see them, you have to actually play through the game. That might sound tautological, but there are rhythm games which understood that a core appeal of their game were the trippy graphics and the synesthetic experience, and thus let you just coast through the game, even if you did extremely poorly, so that you can enjoy the full experience. In contrast, Thumper is fairly unforgiving: your beetle has 2 hit points, and if you make 2 "mistakes" (failling to turn, crashing into a barrier, failing to jump over an obstacle, etc.), you "die" and are sent back to a previous checkpoint.

[b]Games that did it better:[/b] Rez has beautiful visuals that evolve with the music, and shares a similar aesthetic style (though its tone is less gloomy than Thumper's).

[h1]Mechanics[/h1]

The core mechanic behind Thumper is call-and-response. The game will present a rhythm involving both audio and visual cues, and then you're supposed to perform the rhythm back to the game. Unfortunately, there are several flaws with the way Thumper implements this mechanic that makes it unsuitable for fans of rhythm games.

First of all, of the 5 or so different cues that the game presents, only 1 or 2 (depending on how you count them) involve timing. That is to say, the majority of the gameplay in Thumper does [i]not[/i] involve rhythm. There are 5 possible inputs that you can send to the game: Up, down, left, right and action. When there is a glowing spot on the floor, then you need to press the Action button just as the glowing spot passes underneath your beetle. And when you need to perform a stomp-maneuver on the glowing spot, then you need to press the Down button just as it passes underneath your beetle. That's it. For every other cue, you can send the input way in advance of the cue's arrival, and if there are several such cues in a row, you can just keep the relevant button held down to trigger all of them.

For example, there's a horizontal barrier which you can only "break through" if you're holding down the Action button. It's not unusual for these barriers to appear in a syncopated rhythm (e.g. note note pause note pause note note note), but it's not clear what the point of that rhythm is, because what you're supposed to do when you encounter such a cue is to just hold down the Action button through the whole thing.

[b]Games that did it better:[/b] The Rhythm Heaven series is kind of like a Wario Ware for rhythm games: Each song/stage uses the controls in different ways, as if a completely different mini-game. While some of the games might have a "just have the input be held down", they do so for variety's sake, and the majority of the games do ask you to actually perform your input to a rhythm.

[h1]Input Timing[/h1]

This is somewhat related to the previous sections of mechanics, but the input timing on Thumper is completely off, and the reason it's completely off is a direct result of the design decision they made that the inputs should be "held down ahead of time" as opposed to activated as per the rhythm of the music. Find a video of someone playing the first level of Thumper, and then tap your hands on the quarter notes of the song. While you're doing this, pay attention to when the beetle performs a turning maneuvre.

Notice that the beetle turns, and then as the turn ends, a chime plays, and this chime is on the quarter note beat (i.e. synchronized with when you tapped). This is the [i]end[/i] of the turning maneuvre, which means that this is the point at which it's okay for the player to actually release the inputs. Which means the player [i]must[/i] have entered the input at some earlier time, not on the beat.

The game essentially forces you to enter in your inputs "not on the beat", which is very frustrating for a rhythm game. I completely understand their desire to have the chime sound effect land on the beat, or else the game would be frustrating for auditory rather than tactile reasons, but it seems like they could have fixed this design flaw by simply having the chime occur at the [i]start[/i] of the turn, rather than at the end, and have the player perform the inputs for the turn on the beat of the song.

[b]Games that did it better:[/b] Dance Dance Revolution, In The Groove, Beatmania/IIDX, Guitar Hero, etc. all have some concept of "holding down the input". However, they ensured that both the start and the end of these inputs occur on the beat. Further more, they ensured that the "attack" (the moment the player actually presses the input) must occur on the beat (as opposed to Thumper's approach to let the player press the input at any arbitrary point before the beetle needs to perform the maneuvre), which leads to a much more satisfying input experience.

[h1]Cues[/h1]

Probably Thumper's weakest point as a rhythm game is the quality of its cues. The game uses both audio and visual cues in its call and response system. The audio cues by themselves are not unique enough that you can solely rely on them to play the game without memorization. For example, a "turn" will be signaled by a handclap sound effect. However, you won't know, from just hearing the sound clap, whether you need to turn left or right. And again, Thumper only lets you make 2 mistakes before your beetle dies and is sent back, so simply guessing based on the audio cues is not sufficient.

Then what about the visual cues? Here, Thumper struggles due to overprioritizing its aesthetics. The beetle is travelling along a narrow corridor with opaque walls, and the corridor twists and turns. While visually interesting, the end result of this is that when the corridor turns, it blocks the player's view of the upcoming cues. The level design seems to be unaware of this problem, as it repeatedly uses an anti-pattern in several of its stages where the beetle is cued to turn to one side, and immediately needing to turn in the opposite side with no warning (because the cue for the second turn was hidden behind the walls of the curving corridor). When this happens, Thumper is no longer a rhythm game. It becomes a game of reaction time, and/or memorization as you die and then replay that section, but now knowing that two (or three or four) turns in quick succession are going to come.

[b]Games that did it better:[/b] Groove Coaster is a rhythm game in which your avatar follows a curving path. However, it's able to avoid the pitfall that Thumper falls into by having the path be a simple line with no walls, and thus nothing to "block" the cues.

32973637.review:
Thumper presented itself (and was misinterpreted) as the wrong genre. [b]While it is a great runner, it is a terrible rhythm game.[/b] The levels designs prioritize being challenging over matching the background music, and the sounds they made are usually not musical at all. Worse still, because each obstacle makes the same sound every time, what music they can create is very simplistic and repetitive, think a drum set except only one drum can be played at any given time and there is a short delay between any two drum hits. Thumper also progressively add more obstacles to the levels as the player gets more experienced, which is good as a difficulty curve but also mean the music gets even more monotone at the beginning.
[b]However, that doesn't mean it's not fun.[/b] The game is very responsive (as a runner should), the obstacles are intuitive, the UI is clean, and the presentation is very stylish to say the least. If a runner is what you want, Thumper will satisfy that need very well.

Edit: I'm changing my verdict to be positive. I still insist that the music in this game is bad, but once I set my expectation right, the sound effects become very cathartic.

32902997.review:
Thumper is evil. It gets to you in a way that I dont think any other game has managed to. It builds this constant progressive dread that seems to never end up to a never reaching climax. And it does that just by asking you to hit a button when a blue square reaches you, slide on some walls and fly over some obstacles.
I wouldnt go as far to call Thumper a horror game as in its not trying to scare you like Resident Evil or Outlast would, but its a compelling candidate for existential horror, the kind of horror Lovecraft was so enamoured with. And it manages to accomplish this just by the abstraction of its aestethic and its incredible sound design and  industrial techno soundtrack.
In Thumper you are in control of a silver beetle stuck on a track on its journey to the beyond. The game clearly establishes very early on that this is serious business just by the tone of the music playing and it gives you a very brief tutorial before sending you on your way, without much care if you will survive or not. Very quickly you will be struggling to press the button on time with the blue notes that pass by you and the music simply wont let up.
But up until this point, the only punishment you seem to get out of missing these notes is a reduced score. No big deal.
Then, real danger starts to show up. You will have to turn the beettle in time with the turns of the road, and hold down the button when some barriers show up alongside the track. You fail to do this, you lose the beetle's armor. You fail to do this twice, you are dead.
The great thing about Thumper is that the control scheme is very minimal and easy to understand, so the game takes that opportunity and throws you the most violent sequences of notes and obstacles to deal with, leaving you in a constant state of (positive) stress. Sometimes it seems impossible, but the game always gives visual and sound indications of what the next obstacle is, so you soon learn how to deal with it and its immensely satisfying to get an S-Rank on a segment.
The game also has bosses that truly test your skill up to that point and really stand as a barrier to those who arent ready for the next level. The final boss does what great final bosses do: test your skills to the max while also providing a new challenge to overcome not seen in the whole game up to that point.  
Its an amazing and thrilling experience with some of the best surrealist visuals and music to complement it. It leaves you in a state of trance where you stop seeing the notes and just start guessing and predicting where they will be by sound alone, and thats the best compliment I can give to a Rhythm game.

It's discounted below the magic HKD100 mark for me and been on my wishlist a while. If you enjoy any beat-driven game, Cytus (if you have an ipad you MUST get Cytus), Audiosurf, anything with a beat, then get this game now. 

A really nice benefit is you can play any level you like, it's not like a shitty arcade game where you have to start from the beginning each time. If you even decide to quit halfway though a level, it will save your checkpoint. 

The difficulty and pace of the game is set just right, slowly building up to more complex manouvres and you never have to start too far back if you die. 

It doesn't reinvent the wheel, but it's a solid, entertaining game for anyone who likes to hit things to a beat!

32843686.review:
I feel like this game was made for me. 



PROS

-Feels good to play (responsive, never feel cheated out of a life)

-High and stable FPS (nice on 144hz monitors)

-Intuitive. There's no real walkthrough or in game guide, but it's easy to catch on to (almost) everything

-Wide skill range. This game isn't as hard as some of the noobies that left negative reviews might convince you to believe. With a controller and a little bit of time and practice you can beat the game in less than a week, AND there is a high skill ceiling if you want to go for all S rank, AND a much higher skill ceiling if you want to improve your score on the leaderboards (and of course the much more unforgiving newgame+)

-Visuals. The atmosphere is just amazing, fast, and scary just like I never knew I wanted it to be.

-Sound. The sound is 70% of everything good in this game. I cannot give the sound guy enough props. It gets the adrenaline pumping while keeping you on beat and letting you know the beat to come. Brilliant.



CONS

-I wish there were more levels, or at least user made levels. I beat the game twice in <20hrs (1st playthrough + S rank) and even left the game open for a few hours. There's still newgame+, but they're all linear levels. Good for practicing, but it does kill the replayability a bit.

-Lack of an in-game guide. This isn't a deal-breaker for me, but trying to figure out how to stay in the air during turns to hit those high arches consistently was a bit difficult without a guide. Everything else was mostly covered at points in the early levels. 
Note: There is a PDF guide if you right click the game. I found it after I beat it the second time.

OVERALL: 9.5/10

Should you get it?
Yeah. (unless you absolutely hate rhythm games)

这就不得不说一下这个游戏的节奏问题了。游戏的节奏是单纯的音节组成的，这些音节会在你过一段障碍时提前那么一两秒重复一遍，然后你可以按照这个节奏去按键。那么问题就来了，就我游玩的一个小时内，我遇到了两个比较明显的问题：一个就是这段提示的节奏声音相比你按键时的特效音太小了，以至于如果你想连续按对一段，就需要靠目押；另一个就是这个提示音只能体现两种，也就是点（短拍）和线（长拍），但障碍种类却太多，我目前打到了三关过半，其中长拍还好些，我玩到第三关也就只有过弯才是长拍，而短拍对应的障碍物就有三四种，这就导致即使你按照节奏来按，也需要注意障碍类型来做出应对，简而言之，还是要目押。所以总的来说，这并不是一个十分合格的节奏游戏，在游玩这款游戏的过程中，节奏感虽然必要，但显然并不是最主要的，它本质上更偏向需要反应的那种。
既然说到目押，就得说说这游戏的版面设计了。而这个游戏的版面设计，实际上不怎么让人舒服。这个原因主要来自两方面：一方面是作为独立游戏意料之中的优化不到位，当然这个并不是指我们平常说的游戏优化，而是内容、画面和系统上的深层优化；其次就是很多非常恶意的版面设计。
先说一下这个游戏的内容优化。
首先是画面上过多的光污染，虽然游戏做的十分酷炫而且也确实很爽，但画面确实很伤眼睛，我只不过玩了一个小时，退出游戏后却感觉眼睛已经花得难受，这种感觉上一次还是我快十年前初中那时候，熬了两天一夜看小说后有的……当然这个比喻还是有点夸张的，不过不可否认的是，这游戏的光污染的确很严重，虽然背景颜色已经调成了各式各样的暗色冷色，然而频繁而闪瞎眼的特效光依旧瞎眼，高强对比度和高频闪烁光的情况使得眼睛承受的压力远超预期，更别说我上面讲的，这是一个要靠反应和目押的游戏，这就意味着更伤眼睛了。
其次是游戏系统上的优化。这个游戏的游戏设定大多数都很有趣，毛病是有但一般不是很大，唯独只有一点——游戏的判定区设置的很有问题。游戏设置的完美判定点是比较偏后的，这就导致如果想要尽可能保证完美率，就要相应承受更高的miss风险，而这个判定点却是不能调的，这就很尴尬了。虽然很能理解判定点靠后对目押更为友好，但相应的依靠节奏的玩家就会坐蜡了。
而除了这些来自有点毛病的点，来自游戏作者的恶意则更加让人难受。
虽然我只玩到了第三关过了大半，但却已经能体会到游戏的恶意了。
其中最明显的两个恶意就是，跑道加速（物品闪回速度更快，可供反应时间更少），以及恶意遮挡前路情况。
前者我就不说了，后面这个是有点闹心的。游戏常用手法就是故意把跑道弯度设计得更高，导致你看不到拐角后方的路况，然后用连续弯道坑你或者让你miss掉一个点，显然是十分恶意的初见杀；除此之外，就是利用甲虫本身来当做障碍印象视线，在甲虫跃起飞行的时候，画面会被甲虫遮挡很大一块，而游戏就在这后面设计各种障碍，尤其从第三关开始，背板的要求已经越来越大，这显然很不亲民也很影响游戏体验，毕竟你只是节奏游戏，而不是那些大触玩的不背板你连歌都听不完的音游！
总的来说，游戏素质不错，但游玩体验远不如预期，闲暇时打几小关休闲一下不错，玩时间长了太伤眼睛。
评分可以给个7/10，创意和画面效果很好，可惜还有硬伤，推荐打折半价以下购买。

Game sounds great on my bose speakers/subwoofer. Pretty good through my cheap sony extra bass headphones too.
