32461600.review:
Don't get me wrong. I WANT to recommend this game. I just can't.

When it's doing what it's trying to do, the experience is AMAZING. Intense without being frantic, relentlessly heavy and nightmarish in a surreal, visceral way that puts you in a cold sweat. The interface is simple enough not to need words or symbols and demanding enough to always feel desperate and NEVER like you can relax. It demands constant, almost exhausting focus which only adds to the psychically malevolent atmosphere. It's the best worst medicated fever dream you've ever had.

But as exceptional as the abstract horror aesthetic is, the game itself too often falls apart around it, sometimes serving that aesthetic at the player's expense- and not in a positive way like deliberately taking control or awareness away from the player to stress them out. Sometimes for no good reason. During more intense periods the track itself can become warped and distorted- to the point that the visual cues can no longer be read, or they distort in random or unreliable ways the player can't properly parse. The rhythms often get so syncopated that they lose any relation at all to the plodding drums that make up the soundtrack. And in busier passage the hellish noises that come with hitting beats completely drown out the audio cues for the notes still coming- which can be a problem when, as noted, the track becomes too distorted to read.

I grit my teeth and powered through these problems as well as I could for a while because again, when the game works it WORKS. But then new more sophisticated and complex moves were introduced that, without any verbal explanation of any kind, made the TUTORIAL impassable. The moves themselves are baffling to try to execute correctly (by methods that will never be illuminated) with such distorted and arcane feedback that the trial and error to puzzle through them is hopeless.

This would've been one of my all-time favorite rhythm games, but a few core issues make the entire experience too frustrating to revisit, or recommend to anyone. That the issues are so fixable and the game under them is so good just makes it tragic.

Maybe you'll have more patience for it than me! A lot of people clearly did! But otherwise... wait for Thumper 2, I guess.

32061230.review:
Driving beats: ✔
Psychedelic visuals: ✔
Challenging rhythm gameplay that requires non-selective hearing: ✔
snakes and angry spiky skulls: ✔
existential dread: ✔✔✔

the level of concentration this game needs will make any itch on your face 20x more noticeable

the best time to scratch your nose is when there are snakes on screen

Anyway, listen to the soundtrack to see if you're into the ambient beats. I say its good but maybe your sense of music is different. This game's tough as balls and you'll need to make sure you can identify what percussion element is what in order to advance, and that the atmospheric sounds sit well with you.

This game really forces you to use your ears as well as your eyes. If you're listening well enough you'll be able to identify upcoming obstacles before your eyes can even register them (which is important cause auditory reaction time is almost always faster than visual reaction time in humans) and you'll be able to identify rhythmic patterns instead of treating each impulse or bank as an individual element.

Honestly that's where a lot of the negative reviews come from--the failure to augment their reactions with audio cues. Some later levels are intentionally designed so you CANNOT see what comes at the end of a sequence--you have to listen for it, and trying to do it visually is pushing the limits of human reaction time. E.g. if you hear 3 'slaps' you'll know you have to bank 3 times and when you have to, even though you can only see the first turn.

32005715.review:
10/10 This game is original, good, and difficult. Listen to the track before you buy to make sure you are into the type of music in the game. If you aren't, that will be a problem. Unlike other rythm games, this one is not built around diverse choices of music, different songs, etc. There is really only one "song" in this game, and it plays the through the entire game.  This does not detract at all from the experience, since this game really masters the atmosphere it is trying to create. See if that atmosphere looks awesome, and if it does, you will like this game. 

Also, a warning that this game is challenging. I have beaten the first 7 levels and the 7th took me a couple of hours. Rythm alone will not help you succeed in the later levels, because there are tons of off-beats and minor fluctuations to keep you off balance, and you have very little visual time, or audio cues to react to these changes since everything is moving very fast, and sometimes appearing from around a corner. In order to beat the uber-boss on level 7 I had to memorize the pattern. This has turned some people off from the game, but I can say that if you are looking for a challenge, then this game rewards you with intensity, frustration, and that wonderful satisfaction when you finally get that S rank on a difficult part. 

I give the game a 10/10 not because it is the best game ever, but because it does what it intends to do, and does it very well. Also bonus points for originality.

31955553.review:
“You are a space beetle.” It seems helpful to clear that up sooner than later. Certainly not a common choice for video game protagonist, but a unique one that also serves to hint at the feel and art of this game. Featuring a space beetle travelling across a three-dimensional music visualization while battling a disembodied mechanical monster head, Drool’s avant-garde release Thumper is seemingly built on originality. From its self-ascribed “rhythm violence” gameplay, to the atmospheric and mind-boggling visuals that beckon to you right in the start screen, this game was undoubtedly intended to transcend conventional gaming. In many ways, Thumper accomplishes that goal; unfortunately, it falls short in other areas, resulting in a game that I really wanted to love, but just couldn’t.

Read more at https://tiny-spaceship.com/2017/05/25/thumper-2/

The title doesn't lie: This game makes your heart pound! 

PROS:
- Very simple controls for your brain to click to what you see coming at you
- Tests your perception and reflexes
- Immersive graphics and music (the soundtrack is pretty fun)
- Very replayable with challenges that really test your concentration
- Playable for short bursts of time. If you want something that tests your mind for maybe 15 minutes, this game should do the trick.  

CONS
(Note: these are only my opinions on what others may not like)
-  Not the best game for casual players -> unless you like exploding, you'd best be awake and alert when playing this game :P
- Not much variety: the aforementioned challenges comes from replaying the game's levels. Not very fun for people who find tedium in seeing or hearing repeated patterns.
- Very different soundtrack. I personally view this as a good game feature, but it is possible that the music and visuals can be off-putting to some.

31929843.review:
EDIT: I should mention that while I don't play many rhythm games, I agree with the reviews saying that this isn't a very good rhythm game - but I think it is a good game. Some of the timing feels messy, the BPM is a bit weird, but read why I don't think that's important to [i]this[/i] game below.

TL;DR - It feels like if Guitar Hero was trying to kill you, and instead you murdered the hell out of it right back. That feeling is too incredible to miss. Would recommend.

I'm always wary of games that rely purely on their ambience and feeling. Life is Strange and Undertale are mediocre games that I cared about because the characters were sympathetic and kind to me. Payday 2 was an amazing game that really conveyed the feeling of pulling of a heist as if I were in the movie Heat; now it's a continuous, dying meme tumor. Elite Dangerous' sound design and user interface are incredible, and very good at hiding that the game is actually a cash cow which the devs will never develop in a meaningful sense beyond what is required to make people pay for cosmetics. Like pre-ordering, buying a game based entirely on its ambience is something I simply don't do anymore.

Of course, all these rules have an exception. Every so often you hear people raving about a game so hard that you just cave and do it. I made that mistake with Fallout 4, preordering the entire game and its season pass before I realized it was a hunk of trash, like most games directly developed by Bethesda. I'm presenting all these examples, by the way, so that you, the reader, can realize how low my expectations were for Thumper. I assumed that I would be bitterly disappointed, because I couldn't find anything besides the ambience to recommend it. But the ambience, I had heard, was worth it on its own. So I bought Thumper, and prepared for it to be another big mistake in my abusive love-hate relationship with the modern videogames industry.

Booting up Thumper, you're shown a screen that (I believe) just shows you the road your space beetle runs along, without any intensity or scariness to it. You have to push a button to be shown the menu, then you push another and you're thrown right in. The game shows you your first technique - a [i]thump[/i], which is a completely appropriate name for it. The game invokes the same feeling that Dark Souls combat does, a kind of call-and-response viscerality that demands what feels like perfection, but is really just unforgiving enough that when you finally get that timing down, you really feel like [i]you[/i] killed something. This doesn't come through in the tutorial - the tutorial is free of consequences and of major audio or visual impact. When you [i]really[/i] get into it, you're doing turns, crashing through barriers and doing the aforementioned thumps to a percussion-heavy, violent rhythm, like something from a Hans Zimmer film. 

At this point, it becomes clear where the devs were going with the ambience of the game. Knowing when and where to use music is a key part of game design - the early Tomb Raiders, for example, used no music at all unless you did something key to advancement or discovered a new area. They used music to highlight important things, and as such the music really hit you when it happened. The later Tomb Raiders just put music wherever, designed not to be noticed. While I appreciate that videogame soundtracks are often designed not to be noticed, as modern videogames often try to follow the cinematic ideal of having a complete start-to-finish 'score' while also tackling the conflicting issue of players not always proceeding in time with the arranged music like a film would, I think that music for the sake of music is one of the most disappointing things that's happened to the videogame industry today.

Thumper does not have music for the sake of music. For a start, it's a reactionary game, requiring you to do split-second-perfect inputs to 'kill' the barriers, turns, etc. that you face off against (and the devs have called them 'kills', and they're right to do so). The music is vital in setting you up to expect the next thing. The screen is too busy - you need the music to time it perfectly, and even then you don't always get it. But besides that simple, utilitarian function, Thumper's music is constant, oppressive. It feels like being at the bottom of a diving pool, the constant pressure, the darkness and the strength of it making the entire game feel like a struggle, even though the challenge is completely appropriate to a satisfying gaming experience. When I say the devs are right to call the overcoming of an obstacle a 'kill', I mean it - the game makes you feel devastating, and I absolutely let an evil grin cross my face more than once in my half-hour of playing.

The visual design, too, is designed to enhance the ambience. Even doing nothing, your space beetle shakes as it travels, scraping on the ground with a faint hiss. The visual and the sound combine to give an idea of incredible speed that simply wouldn't be possible with a less visually complex game. You are a tiny, destructive silver bullet, and every action you take reflects that. The thumps let out devastating booms as you distort everything for just a moment to [i]destroy[/i] the timed points you thump on. The crashes make you hug the ground, shaking even more violently and throwing up sparks as you [i]obliterate[/i] the barriers in your way. The turns are skin-of-your-teeth, even if you prepared for them well in advance. You feel like a tiny, unstoppable force in a whole universe turned against you. I can imagine that if they existed, this might be what demigods felt like on their incredible, mythical labours. A beetle was the absolutely perfect choice to symbolise all of the forces at work here - protected, armoured and determined with its wings down. When it raises them, it's aggressive, powerful, [i]angry[/i]. 

The damage balance of the game is perfect, allowing you one hit before you're killed - and when you recover health, the wings you lost when you took damage fly back on and click into place with a visual impression like a champion recovering his weapons, or some war-machine reloading a weapon. In short, the game is impeccably designed from an artistic direction. This is the kind of game that is painful to play, because you know the developers may never come across such a stroke of genius again. Well done, Drool, for creating one of the best games I ever played.

This may all seem like a bit much, considering what I said about playing games based on ambience alone. Trust me, I don't expect this game to have infinite replayability. If I ever go for all S-ranks, I think I'll probably completely cease to enjoy the game and lose entirely the elements that make it great. This isn't a game for achievement hunters. This is a game for your dark fantasies, for your power-visions, a representation of what happens in your head when that pulse-pounding anthem of your passion and your anger starts to play on the radio. It's a game about catharsis, and sadly all forms and sources of catharsis eventually lose their impact. But this dark, bitter, hot half-hour of gameplay has been one of the most satisfying of my life. For the shelf-life of the product and the length of the game itself, I would say a price of £10 is more fair than the asking price of £16, but it's worth it either way. If you're wondering if you'll enjoy this game, you will.

A completely different game, with an amazing atmoshpere, very rewarding level design and an awesome soundtrack! The levels get better as you go in my opinion, with the extra added elements and unique visuals (level 7's miniboss is the best stage I've played so far). However, despite the tags and description, this isn't a 'proper' rhythm game. The music is excellent with a lot of crazy metres and so on, but the in game cues are very much different from the audio a lot of the time (ocaisonally you get a simple repetetive rhythm that ties in with the music just fine, but otherwise that isn't the case). You'll probably still enjoy it if you like rhythm games, but it plays in a much different way.

Although this may seem incredibly challening (and it is), it's the kind of challenge that makes you angry at yourself rather than the game, which makes level success even more gratifying. Absolutely 10/10!

Bonus: even though my laptop is pretty crap performancewise, and I have to run in 800x600 to get a fairly reliable framerate, I'm still having a blast!

31820978.review:
Thumper is the video game equivalent of strangling your worst enemy to death. 

It's utterly brutal, mortifying, and at times definitely frustrating, but it dares you to hate it. Ingeniously, the game itself is an outlet for your anger. Every rhythmic beat is explosively violent and deeply satisfying. The combination of all of those hits (or "kills", as the game actually calls successful notes), alongside the terrifyingly beautiful art design, results in the most amazing art game I've ever played. People usually say "art game" to deride something for being both not really art and not really a game, but Thumper is definitely both.

Congratulations to the two (two!!!) developers, and thank you for bringing us rhythm violence.

9/10

Thumper is a very fast paced, beautiful looking "Rhythm"/ Reaction game. I'm having a hard time calling it a rhythm game since big parts of the game solely rely on fast reflexes and muscle memory, so dont expect a game where you cruise around to the music.

That said, Thumper is one hell of a experience. The game already starts out pretty challenging, but ramps the difficulty up higher and higher with every level. Beating the game isnt a very easy task already and requires some dedication. If you want to go for "S" rank on every level you better be prepared for a wild ride, cause that will take some serious commitment.

The best thing about this game is probably the feel of the gameplay. Taking sharp turns with full speed or hitting a flawless segment just feels so satisfying. I really enjoyed my time with Thumper and it delivered a very unique experience, that I can recommend to anyone that likes a little challenge.

31245227.review:
Just when you think you're getting good, when your confidence is soaring, the game will make you curl up into a ball and watch gems fly past you. But you've got to get out there eventually. You've got to get those gems, even if it means dropping your defenses near a rapidly-approaching series of obstacles.

And whether or not you realize it, you'll learn the telegraphs for the turns. A slight tilt of the track, and your finger is already prepared to push in the direction of the upcoming turn.

And once you get really good, you'll beg yourself to quit being reckless. And then you'll jump into the air, slam into a gem, and jump again; You'll remain airborne while artfully turning corners against your will. You don't know if you'll ever be able to pull that off again. But you will.

It's like Rez. Your first playthrough's about surviving. After that, survival's never the issue.

31142457.review:
One of the most difficult questions I've had to answer as a parent came when my son came in while I was playing this and asked me, "What's this game about?"

It's... like guitar hero, but with less buttons.  And you're a beetle on a roller coaster. Which features tentacles and weird geometric shapes and centipedes and things. And the music is something like a drum & bass remix of a horror movie soundtrack. It's somehow simultaneously entertaining and deeply unsettling.

But despite that rather unflattering explanation, it's a good game. It's hard to describe exactly what makes it a good game, but it has my heart beating faster than a liter of energy drink, it's making my hands cramp up from gripping the controller so hard, and it's making me sweat despite it being 68 degrees F in this room, and any game that can elicit that kind of a physical response has got to be good, right?

This game is the biggest motivation I have right now to buy a VR headset because I can only imagine how amazing it would be with one. Or horrifying. Definitely one or the other, and I want to experience that.

30861471.review:
Thumper is a brutal rhythm game that never ceases to be challenging. The heavy music and the abstract, dark art style complement eachother forming not just a very fun game, but a legitimate piece of artwork. The game is divided into 9 levels and each level is split into a couple dozen pieces with a smooth transition between each piece. Every level brings new mechanics that are so good that there is a desire to finish a level just to see the next mechanic. The game is actually easier than it looks, but it is still definitely far from easy. Every obstacle is fine-tuned to match the beat of the song not only by the sound it makes while crossing the obstacle, but also the sound it makes when spawning. In VR, despite the very erratic nature of the game, there is absolutely zero motion sickness, because, technically speaking, the VR camera is stationary and everything moves towards the player. The checkpoints always come on time, none of them feel spaced too far between eachother. But, it is actually easy to miss the checkpoint, which, even though the game still saves, does not get the second health layer back if you encounter an obstacle before.

In conclusion, this game is highly polished and definitely worth buying even in full price. It is very fast paced and hurts your fingers eventually, but that should definitely not deter you from this amazing experience. If you enjoyed Bit Trip Runner, this is a must-have.

30780778.review:
Данная игра — это нечто совершенно странное и удивительное, взрывающее тебе мозг. Настоящий наркотический трип, в котором ты на огромной скорости мчишься сквозь пустоту, буквально ощущая тревогу и страх, ритмично отбивая всё новые и новые части трека. Погружение — особенно в темноте и с хорошим звуком — просто невероятное. К слову, я также опробовал игру на Oculus Rift. Это — совершенно другой опыт, сравнить который нельзя больше ни с чем. Советую прикоснуться к этой игре в виртуальной реальности всем, у кого есть возможность и желание. Вы очутитесь один на один с практически осязаемым тревожным нечто, которое заставит вас поверить в ужас и страх сюрреалистической пустоты. 

Что в целом? Захватывающая психоделическая игра, которая влюбит вас в себя буквально с первых минут и не отпустит, пока вы не доберётесь до самого конца, сломав не один геймпад/клавиатуру. Тем более, что с каждым уровнем виды становятся всё безумнее, атмосфера всё напряжённее и тревожнее, а треки — всё сложнее и сложнее. Поверьте, порой у вас не будет времени даже на то, чтобы почесать руку или моргнуть. Игра этого не простит. Личная оценка — 10/10. В данной игре для меня не оказалось совершенно никаких минусов. Советую всем любителям странного и необычного.

30743186.review:
Before I go on I would like to preface everything I am about to say with, I don't dislike the game and I have a very adept music background, so rhythm is something that I'm very good at and used to feeling.

 It is a very well made game, however, the audio ques for the action commands are flat bad. They do not stand out enough against the very basic beat to make it noticeable when you need to do something at many times.

I would be trying to find the rhythm of a particular section and I end up memorizing the pattern by watching it and doing it over and over rather than actually feeling the beat of the music and reacting based on that beat. When the game is based off rhythm, this is not acceptable.

I still do not think this is a bad game per say, but there are just times when the rhythm part of the game isn't standing out enough to actually feel the rhythm and this is most likely due to the fact that there is so little actual rhythm music in the damn game. I went through a level and all there was in that level was a snare on a pattern that did not deviate at any point with the patterns in the level, to make it worse it was a boss fight. I did not enjoy that boss fight for any amount of time.

The game is good, but the rhythm aspect of the game needs to stand out more and the music needs to support it more otherwise it doesn't feel like a rhythm game, but rather a pattern recognition game.

Also the effect for taking damage is so distorting that it makes it very difficult to recover if you are in a hard section both with the way it affects the rhythm and the view of what is coming toward you.

The game is very much made for VR more than anything else. The view of the game is great and cool and all, but the rhythm aspect of the game (which is the entirety of the game's base purpose) isn't standing out enough to make it good in my opinion.

The instrumentation is the same throughout the entire game. It is always going to be the same metallic drum with an increased increment on the time. (1/4 time 2/4 time etc etc) Due to this the patterns, while increasing in complexity, are beginning to run together and feel the same after 4 levels. 

So after everything is said and done, the rhythm isn't good enough and standing out enough to make it a good rhythm game and the patterns, while they increase in complexity as the game gets higher in level, are very same-y throughout the entire game. The instrumentation is far below average for a rhythm game.

This is a game best suited for those with VR and no one else. I cannot in good conscience recommend this game for anyone without VR.

30728782.review:
Thumper是一款奇怪的音乐游戏——因为它没有“音乐”。
没错，说它是“音乐”游戏是要被人扁的，更合适用于定义thumper的游戏类型称呼应是节奏游戏，甚至可以是“动作冒险”。

====

音乐需要节奏和旋律。连曲调都没有的节拍游戏如何让人投入的方法，一是将节奏的比重加至极致，二是将画面效果做到足够夸张。

嘈杂的打击乐器构成了游戏中乐曲的主体部分。不间断的鼓声、镲片、合成音，带给玩家的是无旋律的不安和高速度的压迫，充斥了整个赛道。大量且高速下坠的音块、尖刺、弯道在按对后产生的反馈和节拍相应成章，产生了一种纯粹用鼓点形成的音调。在熟悉这种节奏后，使用本能来完成逐渐高速的关卡，压迫感和成就感会随着流程的推进而同时加大。

游戏的整个流程分成了大的章节，章节又分成了大量小关，每关之间都有一个舒缓的缓冲期，而关卡的长度被特意设置成长短不一，有的1分钟，有的可能长达3分钟——玩的时候是不知道的。越是长的关卡往往到最后会产生高频的噪音，更让人感到“怎么还没过关”的急促心态，如同过山车一样，面对未知威胁的爬坡阶段，同样是必需而且有趣的一环。

而终究与过山车体验不同的是，玩家再投入，也只是坐在电脑屏幕前静止的人，无法感受失重的快感。怎么办？

……呃，搬出VR啊！……这当然很重要也十分有效，但没有VR呢？

这就是此游戏色彩差异度剧烈，画面风格如此致幻剂般的目的了。因为难以分辨游戏画面中的色块，强迫玩家从葛优瘫改成正坐，紧紧盯着屏幕中跑道的每处细节，按对了？淡蓝色的爆炸光环与背景深色形成明亮的对比，产生十足的反馈。没按对？惨红色的爆炸让游戏的压迫程度更上一层楼。

流程后期添加的敌人“聚能环”（我瞎编的名词），能力是让跑道中的小音块也不能漏，漏了就死。常常看到有人说这个聚能环过大的体积会挡住跑道，影响观感，难度很不合理，我倒是觉得它是故意这么做的，正因为挡住了跑道的一部分，所以才强迫玩家更加紧张地盯着屏幕看。

游戏当然是无情的，正如所有节奏游戏都一样，只能按对了所有的按钮才会呈现出最完美的音质和画面表现。Thumper与其他游戏不同的一点在于，它使用了这种病态的音效和色彩，用强迫的手段的将玩家投入进这个小甲虫的世界，正因为百分百的投入，看着这只发亮发光的甲虫上天入地，拐过致命弯道，完成一次出色表演的时候，玩家才会由衷地发出赞叹，彻底沉迷于这个世界之中。

===

诚然，有限的乐器和已经被限死的“乐器”种类数量的确不足以让游戏产生足够多的音轨让玩家一关关乐此不彼的玩下去。游戏的流畅不算长，游戏如果不求高评价的话，大约7小时即可通关，尽管只有短短的九关，越打到后面会越觉得音乐的节奏已经跟不上音块的轰炸速度了，音块的构成也渐渐趋于同质化。而随关卡推进，游戏最主要的变化，只是越来越快，更让人应接不暇的速度。

不过这并不全是坏事，因此游戏后期的重心则是将节奏的搭配渐渐转移至了受苦带来的挑战欲。高速的音块下坠和哄乱的打击乐带给玩家的则是极具上升的压迫感，虽然很疯狂，但冲破困难阻碍后的一声巨响，能让我长舒一口气，接着大喊一声爽，然后兴奋地期待着下一关的难度。

当然单纯的挑战同样是枯燥的，因此游戏中还添加了BOSS的概念，与其说是BOSS，还不如说是游戏的特殊演出环节。九章中大约每一章插入了2-3位BOSS，在前期BOSS是用来进行新手引导的，而后面的关卡花样自然就来了。直到靠近拐弯点才出现弯道的“无尽直道”，玩着玩着突然原地倾斜角度让人猝不及防的“旋转赛道”，还有赛道时快时慢分不清节奏的“时间紊乱”等等（名字依旧是我瞎编的）。这些BOSS的特殊设计是一个不错的调味剂，也让游戏有了些许的目的性，操控着我们的小甲虫跑完这些变态赛道后发出的道道冲击波打在BOSS脸上，在相对重复的赛道设计添加了一定的活力。

===

你可以说，Thumper是一个只有色彩夸张，音效嘈杂，毫无章法，只会把人震的头晕目眩，剩下什么都没有的“LSD软件”。我也可以说，正是这样一个纯粹而极致的概念将游戏本质的真面目给挖了出来，我在thumper中感受到了高速的压迫，挫败，无尽的折磨，然后因此又获得了打中节拍反馈带来的刺激感，以及胜利的成就感，无论是痛苦还是喜悦，它都是游戏本应带给玩家的一部分，其实也是游戏最原始的目的。

这个目的，可以称之为，享受。
而Thumper能给我带来的 “享受”程度，是120%。

30713314.review:
Thumper is a greatly challenging, exhausting and absolutely gripping, and truly athmpsoheric experience that had me reel from its truly terrificly creepy bosses.

You race along a track and to the rhytm of the music have to perform maneuvers like evading bariers left, right, pushing a button the minute you reach a light on the track, jump and fly of a specific amount of time and block attacks.
The palette of these maneuvers becomes bigger and bigger as well as the the way the track shows itself. For example the track later gets multiple lanes that it counts to navigate on top of everything else.

It's perhabs biggest hurdle is this, the rather quickly surmounting difficulty. 

If you are not a fan off repeating the same stages again and again then i would advice to stay away since this will simply a big part of the experience and the nature of this game.

The difficulty offers also another problem, at least to me personally. Since you first need to get into the rhytms and immense speed in wich the game challenges you it is difficulty to pick the game up just like that. You will have to play the whole thing over again or it will take even more retries to get back into the rhythm and speed of the different levels.

30679869.review:
I have very few rythm games I have ever taken a liking to. The DDR craze along side Guitar Hero type games were never  really my thing. The last rythm game I was really impressed with was Pa-Rappa, its quirky characters and super memorable songs hit just the right spot. It's been a long time since that game, and I always wished something would impress me the way that title did for the rythm gene...enter Thumper.
Unlike Pa-Rappa there is no story, quirky charaters, or zany ass songs...hell its not even like Thumpers soundtrack could be considered a song, more like a drumtrack from hell (but still so good). This is Rythm at its core.
I'm only on the 3rd level as of now, and I can tell you its a white nuckle affair. Super trippy graphics play perfectly to a soundtrack to get your heart pumping, and controls that are spot on. I have read elsewhere that someone said there was  lag after an update. I had no such problems, everything worked great with my 360 controller.
People looking for more than arcade rythm game might look elsewhere. This is not a story driven game, nor should it be. When a game is this slick, gameplay wins over story. Its all about hitting the jumps, turns, and marked location with the correct presses of the d-pad and the A button at the right times. You don't have real freedom of movement, but soon in you'll realize you wouldn't want it anyways. You'll be too busy just trying to stay alive, and 2 misses and it's game over. It's hardcore, and it's fun. A must buy.

但游戏也存在问题，视觉特效有点过分绚丽了，玩时间长了很容易出现视觉疲劳，而且真的有点挡视线了，尤其是连续急弯的情况下很容易眼花，音乐上很应景很带感，但确实有点单调了，希望以后可以开发出其他曲目的玩法，能升级成真正的音游那是极好的，这两条让人很难持久的去玩这个游戏。
游戏虽然主打VR但没有VR效果也是很棒的，[b] 最重要的是一定要有个好的低音炮	[/b]，当然如果能用VR那肯定是更爽的拉，[strike] 能嗑了药再玩估计会更爽	[/strike]
另外，吐槽两点，steam游戏简介中文页面机翻的吧，“节奏暴力游戏”、“残酷的肉搏“，这有点误导了吧，然后，中文译名有点傻

30660886.review: This game has an amazing soundtrack, great visuals and air tight controls (for xbox 360 not sure if its the same for any other) but if you play this you will sweat, you will cry, you will break your fingers (I seriously break my fingers everytime I play this gets so frustiating) but above all its worth it. 30659829.review:
I was sceptical when I got this game, despite all the good reviews. The Pictures and the video looked as if there isn't variety in this game and I wondered if this feels like a Mini-Game you play for a few Minutes like some shallow Smartphone games.
It took like 20 Minutes and I was completely sucked in.
I must admit, I am not a big fan of the soundtrack, not because it is bad, but because its not the kind of music I listen to. BUT it fits incredibly well and it is needed to create the package. And maybe that's exactly the success formula of this game: It is a perfect package.
The visuals alone are psychedelic and if you look at them alone without playing or hearing the music, it's nothing special. The gameplay itself is polished, but nothing that hasn't been done before. But if you take it all together, it's so complementary, that you get an truly awesome immersion.
The pure speed which makes the gameplay thrilling, the beats which lets you literally feel the track, the flow you get... I don't remember anything I can compare it to.
I can imagine that you can play this game for hours without getting bored... Cleary recommended!

30659761.review:
This game really shines in VR

30654250.review:
This is a REVOLUTIONARY rhythm game, rising up to perhaps the first true modern rhythm game. It goes beyond the traditional design of using icons to tell you what to press found in games like Parappa the Rappa, Dance Dance Revolution, Guitar Hero, and Beat Mania. Thumper goes beyond it by telling you what to press visually. The ominous repetitive drum rolls give you the tempo needed for you to have sense as to what goes on, and the visual & sound queues come up just a couple seconds before they are needed to activate.

There is an awesome sense of reward if you land certain queues correctly, which may give you a shield if you don't already have one, to simply a neat effect complementing it with point multipliers. The boss battles could get intense and require several tries to beat them since that is when the queues become even more unpredictable but fair enough to queue you if you react in time.

At first my impression of the first level was "Okay, this is kinda cool." By the time I was on the third level the game began to get so difficult but was hooked at the sound effects, the combos that the game teaches you, original dark ambient/techno-ish soundtrack which progressively gets more complicated, and deceptively simplistic mechanical control. All these factors make you want to BEAT the level.

This is an AMAZING and REVOLUTIONARY game, giving you the right amount of difficulty and queue time to get better. Thumper should not be missed.

30149025.review:
Never before has a story about a metal bug reaching the singularity been so thrilling. This rhythm game cares less about the music you're trying to match and more about whether you survive its onslaught or not. Each level is an endurance test laced with adrenalin and boss fights with only slight breathers sprinkled in. Between that and it's very surreal visuals, it's a brilliant jump-start to the senses and one hell of a substitute for caffeine. 

Having said all this, wait for a sale. $20 is a bit much for a game that stops varying its obstacles mid-way through and the faster it gets, the harder it becomes to tell what's ahead thanks to the visuals becoming a blurred mess or red and silver. (This is why you don't speed, kids.) Not just that, but there should be a penalty for games that only offer health when you're playing well...meaning that you don't need the health when you're rewarded with it 90% of the time. Just adds salt to the wounds from crashing cus' one level is kicking your ass and you can reeeeeeeally use that health the game spat out last level. That fact is especially true in boss fights. The health refill only appears when you do a section perfectly the first time. The only way that system works is through trail and error and again, by then you generally don't need it when you're given it.

Another thing is by about world 5, the game gets hard. By world 6, you're expected to master everything, even techniques never taught to you. For example, you can bounce. Game never taught me that, but the game expected me to have perfected this hidden technique. You told me how to slam down on the ground from the air, why not tell me how to stay in the air? That goes double for those arches that appear long past your normal flight strength. I still haven't figured out how to get them cus' the game never told me.

Still, despite the grips, it's a fun curiosity that's worth trying. Where else can you go fight a giant devil doughnut?

30007161.review:
So I've played this game on and off for a while now and I think it deserves a review. I stumbled upon this game when I watched an unrelated Gaming Video with short scenes of this game spliced into it and knew I had to have it just by the looks of it, so I bought it on sale and haven't been disappointed.
Thumper is a rythm game. It's also kind of a horror game with lovecraftian themes. Controls are simple. You have a Stick with four directions and a button, the game throws you the beats and some obstacles and then it goes like this: *THUMP*---*THUMP-THUMP*--*CLING*-*THUMPdangdang*---*THUMPdadingSrrrrrrrrrrrrr*---*WUMP*. Or something like that. The game just feels great. I think what sets it apart from other rythm games is that it's not only important to hit the beat at the right time (the hit window is actually pretty generous) but also that you have to keep the button pressed to not crash into obstacles and release it at the right time to get the next beat. Then add some basic horizontal and vertical movement and you have a simple yet challenging and fun game.
The Game is hard but fair (in most cases, some obstacles you can't possibly see coming), you can repeat any checkpoint without punishment, if your reaction time is lacking you can always memorize the patterns. But you will still die a lot, because the game is fast and you only get two chances before you die. But the game also eases you into it, the first 4 levels are basically tutorial, Level 5 is where things get rough and you struggling just to survive. It also is the kind of game where it is really fun to play it again after you have beaten it just to see how much you have grown as a player and how easily you can get an S-Rank on a part you struggled so hard before.
Overall two thumbs (thumps?) up, highly recommended.

29709214.review:
[h1]If you own a VR headset, this is a must-have. [/h1]

I've only ever reviewed one other game and that was just to satisfy the steam community badge. Needless to say, this game exceeds my expectations- no this game has become [u]the standard, the pinnacle for VR seated experiences[/u]. I've had my Vive since launch and have played most everything room scale. I didn't think a seated VR game would even come close to the level of immersion experienced via other room scale games but this takes the cake. 

Gameplay - [b]10/10[/b]
While not entirely rhythm based, Thumper lends itself to a series of visual and audio cues to alert the player. Quick reactions, and keen foresight are needed to obtain the highest score for each level. I find myself replaying levels and checkpoints just to get the coveted S rank. Mistakes are pounded into you in Darks Souls fashion.  

Visuals - [b]10/10[/b]
Astounding, exemplary, beautiful. I run a GTX 1070 so there's no lacking in graphical throughput. That said, the visuals throughtout are as smooth as a car ride in the countryside. Despite being a roller coaster-esque experience, the visuals don't overshadow the sense of scale, and wonder as you zoom through the obstacles. The geometrical shapes and patterns accompanying the ride flow like a river. There are moments of muted austerity, which is then contrasted by an elongated grandeur. 

Sound - [b]10/10[/b]
Imagine laying down for an MRI. You're semi-naked in the patient garbs, and you're being slowly thrusted down this tube of magnets and xrays. The incoming radation that will blast through your body is unnerving at first, and you don't realise how it affects you until the doctor shows you your results. This is what the OST to this game does. It accompanies you on a journey and heightens your senses. Like laying there defenseless, you let it overtake you, embrace you at times. Harsh, almost industrial at times, but soft, and orchestral at others. Perfectly balanced for levels, and bosses. 


[i]Every sound, every light, every movement is orchestrated to provide a thrilling, terrifying, and mesmerising experience. [/i]

29613534.review:
As an avid fan of rhythm, amospheric, and horror games, I had to give this a try. I saw it on sale and grabbed it for $14.

It was totally worth it. 

By far, the most unique rhythm game I've ever played. I mean, the closest thing I can compare it to is either Audiosurf or Amplitude (2015). But that's kind of a stretch.

First of all, the difficulty as you complete levels scales damn near perfectly. It introduces new machanics and controls as you go along just enough to keep it interesting and challenging without throwing too much stuff at you to deal with. 

It took me about 10-11 hours to beat all of the songs. Each song/level takes about an hour to complete, assuming you'll miss some sequences sometimes and have to start over at a checkpoint. I was worried that I wouldn't get enough playtime out of this game but even after beating it, I want to revisit the levels again and try to get an S rank on all of them. I can see myself getting another 5 or 10 hours out of this game easily. 

ALSO, it's VR supported. I don't have a headset, but you can bet your ass this is the first game I'd play if I got one.

In short, if your a fan of rhythm games or just experimental dark indie games, this is a must play.

This is a fantastic rhythm game that is absolutely worth checking out.

The pacing is perfect for new players (minus a single nitpick), the difficulty is astronomical in the later levels, but still forgiving in the sense that respawns are fast and the game is consistent (minus a single nitpick), and the music is pretty good.
Global leaderboards are a neat addition that give everyone a goal to reach for.

Thumper is a rythm game. Right now at level 6 there are only few inputs you have to get right. Up, down, left, right, with or without pressing button A.

I find this game very hard, because often I just don't recognize any rythm, that I could get in sync with. There are just so many Beats, Breakbeats, Off-Beats that I sometimes just play as well with the sound off. On the other hand it is still exciting to play. 

It can be frustrating at times, when you could swear you pressed the right Buttons at the right time and you die and you look at your hands and see your fingers still pressing the right buttons. But that might as well be due to input-delay (wireless-controller) or output-delay (sound).

I'd like to have some easy-mode, where you have more armor or larger time-windows for input. 
And I wished a hundred times to see a record of my play together with the input to see what went wrong. 

Nonetheless. The game is very challenging and visually impressive. I like it for occassional playing when I don't have much time. I cannot play Thumper for more than one hour without pause, because it requires so intense concentration.

Thumper is a particularly interesting game, in that it uses only a stick and a button, but still manages to be one of the hardest games I've ever played.
Think of it as Audiosurf, but you're on PCP and Cocaine and you're fighting monsters by punching lights on the floor. Sounds cool, doesn't it?
The first few levels start off relatively easy, giving you warnings and prompts, and from then on game slowly eases you into a blender called rage and hatred. And by 'ease', I mean it throws you in at the speed of sound.
This is the most rage/depression-inducing, anus-clenching, flashy-neon game I've ever played (besides perhaps Hotline Miami, which I also recommend checking out), and I love it. I think.
Try not to break your controller.
7.5/10

29132924.review: Thumper is undoubtedly one of the best rhythm games I have ever played. It is fast-paced, difficult, and has pulse-pounding rhythms that stick in my head weeks after having played it. I cannot recommend this game enough.

29128328.review:
Calming strings play softly as you glide down the track, tripply fractal visuals lull you into a zen sense of wonder and you loose yourself in the moment... until the kettle drumming starts up once again and pulls you back into focus as a new onslaught of turns, barriers and barricades comes hurling at you, with only the rhythm to save you.
Let me get the bias out of the way, I LOVE rhythm games. Nothing blisses me out more than getting to that place where the music is king and all you're doing is reacting to is. 
Thumper is a champion of this, like Rez, the trippy visuals only enhance what is ostensibly a largely audible experience. 
I tried playing this with headphones for a while, but cranked up speakers, ones with really good bass, is where it's at for this. You'll find yourself picking up audio clues all over the place to help you navigate the roller coaster.
A lot of effort was put into making the experience here viseral, this isn't a simple navigation of multi track mixing like in Aplitude or Frequency. This is a roller coaster ride of audio violence that lets you feel your mistakes. If you fail, you fail hard, with only one shield shell to make protect you. The checkpoint system is incredibly forgiving though, and with levels that go on upwards of 10 minutes or more, they're really nessesary. You can back out, and return to the part of the level you left on at any point. 
Right now, I can't find anything to complain about. Like all rhythm games, sync is important, so if you're playing on an HDTV, you might find a bit of lag between the video and the audio. For a game that requires such precision, it kinda does suprise me that there doesn't seem to be an input lag adjuster present in the game.
Anyway, yes, I highly recommend this game if rythm games are your jam.

29126862.review: A rhythm game with a severe and oppressive aesthetic. Long and trance-inducing levels where the goal is to survive rather than keep perfect rhythm. The scoring has more depth than most rhythm games do. Great difficulty curve that eases you in but doesn't hold your hand.

29111176.review:
No words, no backstory, no bullshit. You're thrown onto a space rail at blistering speed and promptly begin to Thump for your life as the game introduces the basics with short, deeply immersive tutorial segments. Thump. Bank to survive corners. Slide through obstacles, hover above deadly traps, and more as you complete the first few levels.

Words cannot do justice to the intensity of Thumper's gameplay. The visual/audio design is fabulous and will immediately make you feel its trademark "rhythm violence". The adrenaline really builds up as the segments get longer, faster and more twisty. And oh my god, the MUSIC. It just fits perfectly within this brutally psychedelic universe.

Hardcore. With its ever-increasing speed and rhytmic complexity, Thumper gets hardcore real quick, or surely feels that way. But never the wrong kind, the punishng, the restart-your-entire-level hardcore (unless you choose the Play+ mode). As challenging as they become, the segments are never unreasonably long and you get a checkpoint at the end of each one, with as many retries as you need. Thumper is perfectly possible to enjoy on a casual level, although the Leaderboards will make you cry a little inside. Yet the subtle scoring mechanisms may well make you feel like the levels you've already beaten have a bit more potential and depth than you thought... and nudge you into inflicting some of that rhytmic violence upon yourself again.

Thump, get thumped. Play Thumper.

29082701.review:
The following is an excript from H.P. Lovecraft's The Music Of Erich Zann. It's also an accurate review of Thumper, especially in VR.

"I heard a sound myself; though it was not a horrible sound, but rather an exquisitely low and infinitely distant musical note, suggesting a player in one of the neighbouring houses, or in some abode beyond the lofty wall over which I had never been able to look. Upon Zann the effect was terrible, for dropping his pencil suddenly he rose, seized his viol, and commenced to rend the night with the wildest playing I had ever heard from his bow save when listening at the barred door.

It would be useless to describe the playing of Erich Zann on that dreadful night. It was more horrible than anything I had ever overheard, because I could now see the expression of his face, and could realise that this time the motive was stark fear. He was trying to make a noise; to ward something off or drown something out—what, I could not imagine, awesome though I felt it must be. The playing grew fantastic, delirious, and hysterical, yet kept to the last the qualities of supreme genius which I knew this strange old man possessed. I recognised the air—it was a wild Hungarian dance popular in the theatres, and I reflected for a moment that this was the first time I had ever heard Zann play the work of another composer. . . .

Then I remembered my old wish to gaze from this window, the only window in the Rue d’Auseil from which one might see the slope beyond the wall, and the city outspread beneath. It was very dark, but the city’s lights always burned, and I expected to see them there amidst the rain and wind. Yet when I looked from that highest of all gable windows, looked while the candles sputtered and the insane viol howled with the night-wind, I saw no city spread below, and no friendly lights gleaming from remembered streets, but only the blackness of space illimitable; unimagined space alive with motion and music, and having no semblance to anything on earth. And as I stood there looking in terror, the wind blew out both the candles in that ancient peaked garret, leaving me in savage and impenetrable darkness with chaos and pandemonium before me, and the daemon madness of that night-baying viol behind me."

29050519.review:
I really wanted to like this game, but I honestly just can't get into it. 

I've made it about halfway through the campaign levels, and I think I just have too many problems with it to keep pushing through. Musically, the levels are basically indistinguishable, and the only thing that changes as you progress is the complexity/game mechanics of what they require you to do. Normally, that would be fine, and it would essentially play out as an experience of familiarizing yourself with the gameplay mechanics and feedback loop to the point that by the end of it you feel like some musical badass as you're whizing through fantastically complex arrangements using the skills you've developed throughout the previous levels, but that just isn't happening with me. 

Halfway through the game, I feel barely more comfortable with the gameplay than when I started. As others have stated, it's a loop of call-and-response where they overlay patterns in the soundtrack that give you a heads up as to what is about to occur on the track. Generally, you can also see what's coming up on the track ahead, too, but sometimes, the track procedes in a way that just doesn't make it visually possible to see what's ahead, and at that point, it just becomes "well, I hope you heard that barely audible queue sequence well enough to distinguish it from the booming core beat". And when you crash after you don't hear that and you begin to repeat the section, it just becomes a game of rote memorization to get through the track. This problem doesn't occur in the early tracks, but that's because they're too slow to really be interesting. Then, by the time the action speeds up to the point that it would be interesting, the audio queues get drowned out in the action.

I don't know, in the beginning, it is really cool, and with a good pair of headphones and if you turn out the lights, it honestly is quite intense. Just don't expect much once the initial rush wears off and you settle into the grind. Maybe on sale it'd be a decent buy, but honestly, I've felt a better "flow" while playing in almost every other rhythm game I've played, and that's including randomly generated ones like Audiosurf.

Thumper is a decent to poor rythm game, but has many frustrating elements which lead to it becoming very borig. Vissually, it looks great, especially in VR.

While the game is a rythm game, I never feel like I can get into the rythm like I can with most rythm games. Even still, the game often repeats the same subsequence in the game several times, so you can learn it that way. A few bosses require the pound move to complete, but I could only get the pound move to work around a third of the time. When a boss required several pounds to be performed in a row, I ended up repeating that section several times (for at least 10 minutes) before being able to progress. At that point, the boss became boring. He could not hurt me because his attacks were trivially easy to dodge, and I could not hurt him because I could not pound consistently.

Visually, the game is quite breathtaking, but you can't really stop to enjoy it. If your looking for a game that gets you into the zone in VR, this might be what your looking for, but the near random nature of the music keeps you from really honing in on the rythm.

28884481.review:
This game can really wear you down, but not that that's bad. You've already lost your shell which means one more miss and you're dead, you're barely hitting everything that's necessary and missing all the extra stuff, and then you finally make a fatal mistake before the end of the level and you attempt it again. Learning from your mistakes is key in this extremely different rhythym game. 

It takes everything you know and flips on it's head. The game eases you into new concepts with each level then pounds you into submission as it gets exponentially harder and faster until you finally reach the level boss which is, in it's own way, a summation of the level you just went through. The boss plays with you at first then gets serious as it realizes you're a worthy foe. Sometimes you find yourself smashing through the levels at a breakneck pace and the game rewards you with a break. A chance to breathe a sigh of relief until you're breaking obstacles and flying over spikes again.

This game is a lot of fun for me, it's crazy, cacophonous, dissonant, yet ties it all together in a great package called Thumper. A very fitting name for the percussive soundtrack to which your silver beetle races to down the single dimension that is all you know for 10 long, grueling, painful levels.

28855740.review:
Thumper is a really neat game that is not for Rhythm Action purists.

'Presentation' is usually a secondary goal for Rhythm Action games.  It's generally considered to be of critical importance that the track is readable and consistent.  Thumper says that ideaology is bunk and and puts presentation front and center.  The two major consequences of this are that it 'feels' really good to play when you are in the zone and doing well.  There is a lot of visual reinforcement for nearly every action and it really is a pretty unique experience in the RA genre.  The other consequence of this is that any kind of mistake generates a lot of implicit punishment.  That visual reinforcement becomes visual noise that you have to see through to try and recover.  The audio stutters and breaks when you make a mistake, making it that much more difficult to find your flow again.  Whether or not you doing well, Thumper is a noisy game.

This kind of presentation extends to effects where you do things right as well -- 'Thumping' on a gem from the air (An action that is not only good, but generates a bonus for the player) causes the track to stutter for an audio effect and generates a big graphic that ripples along the entire track, distorting it all along the way.  Coming from a more traditional Bemani line up of games, these kinds of effects feel extremely disruptive and I honestly shy away from doing them lest I generate more noise in an already noisy environment.

The contrast of the world doesn't help.  Often times you'll find gems on the track colored bright blue, along with the rails, the background and some of the 'tunnel' objects.  It makes parsing the screen pretty difficult at time.  The contrast of the track 'notes' ranges from acceptable to very questionable throughout the game.

Beyond that, there are a handful of track layouts that are borderline not fair.  You don't get a reasonable amount of time to actually react to some elements, specifically some turns that come out immediately after another turn.  These are pretty rare, but encouraging memorziation as part of learning a track is generally Not Cool™.

I'm ragging a lot on this game and pointing out stuff that irked me some, but I think it's as important to note that I really do enjoy this game and in the whole scope of things, the game is very nicely polished and delivers a truly unique experience that moves the needle in an interesting direction for the RA landscape.  I can't wait to check it out in VR!

If you are a hardcore RA purist, then be ready to make some track readability concessions in favor of graphical and audio flair, but if you just want a fun, unique Rhythm game with an emphasis on presentation, then you really can't go wrong here.

28818745.review:
I bought this game expecting awesome visuals, and boy does it deliver. I've played it exclusively in VR, and it's an amazing experience from that angle. 

However, where it really suffers is the soundtrack. For a rhythm game, the soundtrack is *essential* and unfortunately, this game's music really disappoints. It is, for the most part, monotonous droning and repetitive, overcompressed cinematic-style drumming, interspersed with synth drumkit samples as in-game sound effects. "Overcompressed" is really the important takeaway. There's hardly any dynamic contrast anywhere, and the mixing is middling at best, with hardly any lows and a heavy top end that only distracts from the in-game sound effects. I played the game with my sony MDR-v6's and then listened through the OST again on a pair of DT 770's to see if it improved outside of the game, and it was actually worse, as the best low-end actually came from one of the in-game effects.
While I think the style of the music is promising outside of this context (with a bit of mixing to get the drums more into the foreground), it doesn't fit the fast-paced rhythm game and only serves to detract from the experience.  

Spiel out of the way, this is still an excellent game, especially in VR, as the visuals are absolutely amazing, and the rhythm components are quite well executed despite the mediocre backing music.

28813385.review:
Thumper is the best music game I've ever played, and one of the best designed games I've ever played full stop. At first I thought it was a lot like the classic BIT.TRIP Runner series but moving forwards in 3D instead of sideways in 2D. However, after completing the first couple of levels Thumper seriously comes into its own, over and above other music/rhythm games. As the pace and complexity picks up, so too does the tension - and that feeling of tension is increased by the creepy, drug-trip-gone-wrong visuals and 'thumping' (see what I did there) industrial soundtrack. 

As the game got tougher (I'm on Level 4 of 8 and it's already hurting my thumbs) I found myself barely even consciously registering what I was doing and reacting subconsciously to the audio and visual cues - this is usually what's referred to as a state of 'flow' and I've never had a game induce this feeling quite as much (I would say Super Hexagon comes close).

Above all else, the game feels finely-tuned and very well thought out, every level slowly ramping up in difficulty and adding new concepts in an almost seamless way.

If you're a fan of tough rhythm-based games such as Super Hexagon and BIT.TRIP Runner, this is a no-brainer. And if you have a VR headset, play with that too, I found it massively enhanced the experience.

I actually have no idea where to start with this review. 
uhh... 

Thumper is a game like no other, honestly I haven't seen anything like it.
The way the Developer described it is the only real way to summarise/categorise this game; Rhythm Violence.
It's Utterly Violent, without there being any real form of violence. All in all, Thumper is a Violent Rhythm based game with an amazing soundtrack and a wonderously horrific setting that will have you hooked until completion.

28752897.review:
Thumper is fine. There's absolutely no variety to it, it's extremely overpriced, and if you're looking for a rhythm game, you might get sick of Thumper really quickly. Why? Because it's not a rhythm game as far as I'm concerned. There's absolutely no structure to the "music" you're playing, so the early levels revolve around you listening to audio queues that come a bar before the note they correspond with. It's a game of call and response, kind of like Simon, but on rails. After a few levels, the audio cues become completely and utterly impossible to decipher. Then Thumper becomes a game purely about memorizing the most boring and repetitive levels I've ever seen in a rhythm game. The boss fights are all identical. The levels are all identical, with identical music. The visuals are impressive until you realize that there's no variety to those either. Every level looks exactly the same. This game looks, feels, and plays like a procedurally-generated game, but then you get to the end and there's no more.

Maybe if the game had gone with a more readable art style (as opposed to the twisty-turny tracks that are constantly preventing you from seeing what's ahead), maybe it wouldn't be so frustrating. When you fail, it's not because you didn't stick to the rhythm or you made a mistake - 90% of the time, it's because the game decided to make you take a sharp right immediately followed by a note you couldn't see and an audio cue that you can't fucking hear. 

The game's not buggy or broken, it's just an interesting experiment that makes too many missteps for me to enjoy it. I'm a lover of rhythm games, I'm a fan of quick-fire high-difficulty challenges, and Thumper seems to provide both at first glimpse, but it soon becomes a struggle against trial-and-error level memorization and a control scheme that works against the game's fast-paced nature. The music is good, but it's not good enough to be reused on every single level with no variation apart from the nonsensical rhythms you're beating your ship against. Wait for a sale if you're still interested, the game's worth money, it's just not worth the asking price and the game has a disappointing amount of variety. No alarms, no surprised. Just memorizing headache-inducing levels to a looped beat you'll hear dozens of times per level.

Thumper makes me feel like I need a cigarette break after I finish a single level, and I've never even smoked before.

Edit: I really feell like I should do this game justice and expand on that pithy one-liner review. You might be looking at screenshots of this game and thinking 'it's just Audiosurf and I played Audiosurf so why would I buy another Audiosurf'. But Thumper is not Audiosurf. For sure, it's on a track, it's got crazy psychedelic visuals, and it's rhythm-based, and that's Audiosurf. But Thumper is suffocating. It's panic-inducing. It's a f'ing metaphor for this crazy ride we call life, a constant uphill battle of curveballs flung at you right, left and centre where you're given no freedom to dwell on what the best action might be, just let your lizard brain take over and act on the instincts that the flashing lights and clanging sounds tell it to do. Thumper is a transcendental experience. Play Thumper. Live Thumper.

28738773.review:
[strike]This is not a "thumbs down" so much as a "slightly more negative than neutral" review. I'm by no means saying this game is not worth your time, but the price is a bit much for what you get if you do not have a VR headset (which I suppose is the target audience). This game is fun when it works, frustrating when it doesn't. It's hard to explain the difference but I'll try to summarize it because there really isn't much detail to get into.[/strike] I've completely changed my mind, because of the few mechanics added since I last played. I was avoiding adding time due to how Steam refunds work but now there's enough for me to jusitfy the $16 I spent. I would still recommend waiting for a sale however if it's above this price.

Sometimes the game gives you great visual/audio cues as to what you need to do, and sometimes it basically just throws additional steps that are not telegraphed at all and you need to rely purely on reflexes. I have no clue if that's me missing a cue, if it's intentional, or something else, but it's frustrating when it does happen because it doesn't feel like I'm the one who messed up, although I very well could have. Tunnels limit how far you can see ahead, and since walls don't have a significant visual cue you'll end up getting hit a lot in a way that feels more cheap than fair. 

The game looks great but you can't enjoy the visuals without messing up, so that's just annoying, and I can't imagine playing this in VR without dying constantly. Some level segments will instantly segway into the next one, meaning you cannot look at your score/rating without immediately missing something. This just seems like an oversight and I question why it's in the game. The 2x score indicator is also distracting but I might just be nitpicking (I think you can disable this by turning the entire HUD off but haven't tried).

My largest complaint is how hoops work, because they're so frustrating I might end up refunding the game because how agitating they are. They're so bewilderingly fickle I actually think they might be broken. In order to break hoops, you must press A and IMMEDIATELY hold up on the left stick, something that feels like it doesn't work around 20% of the time. There's also a mechanic that enables you to hit buttons by slamming down on the left stick, which ALSO only works around 20% of the time unless it's a scripted part of the track. It's almost like they didn't expect you to do this unless it was clearly indended by the obstacles. It's so much fun and I want to love this game but it ends up being more frustrating than enjoyable for me, maybe I'm just bad but man I cannot play a full level without feeling cheated at least once.


If this was baseline $15 maybe, but $20 is a bit steep for how basic this game is at its core. Far be it from telling people how to price things, I don't think I'll get my money's worth though. This game is far from bad, but I do NOT understand the overwhelming praise it seems to be getting.


EDIT: Again everything here is still true, but it's too fun for me to keep this review "thumbs down". This is more of a tenative recommendation however, so if you're not interested in what you see in the trailer I'd avoid it.

28645903.review: This is a review for the game played on an HTC Vive only.  I purchased specifically to play in VR as soon as support was added by the developers.  Something is very strange with the stereo rendering in VR.  The near track and bug look 3D, but the track in the distance becomes 2D, and every boss battle looks like you are staring at a 2D cinema screen up close, with the boss showing as a projected movie.  And when your bug explodes, debris close to you again looks 2D.  This sadly detracts from the game in VR, and at one point I was trying to fight a boss with one eye closed to try to fool myself into "believing" that everything was actually in 3D.  The game could have been amazing in VR, but this strange 2D-ness totally ruins it.  From the Discussion page, the devs are aware of this, but seem to suggest that there is no possible fix and that it is a failure of VR as a whole that far away objects look flat and only object at a virtual distance of 1 to 3 metres will ever look 3D.  I am really not sure this is the case, given a large number of other games made for VR (as opposed to having VR bolted on a 2D game like this) work fine, and so as it stands I cannot recommend this game for VR.  Sorry.

28579855.review:
As someone who's not really keen on rhythm games, I bought this game almost entirely on the aesthetic, which is cool as hell. 
Gameplay is really solid, and it feels as much like a racing game as it does a rhythm game. The gameplay feels visceral,  thumpy (you guessed it), and responsive (for the most part). I only hope I'm good enough to keep playing.
EDIT: I was good enough. I don't usually come back to games after I've finished them, but I've enjoyed playing through New Game Plus and doing S rank runs. 
It's actually quite a forgiving game, as you can just skim by on C ranks, barely keeping yourself alive, or go for perfect S/S+ runs - and these two mentalities they're as different as night and day. I would say don't worry about your skill level coming in to this game. You'll pick it all up along the way, and if you keep at it, you'll be doing things you would have thought were impossible.

Suggested playing order:
Standard Game (just try to survive!)
New Game Plus (don't worry about perfect corners that much)
Standard Game S rank run (here's where you should really focus on mastering perfect corners!)
New Game Plus S/S+ rank run

28579211.review: Absolutely exceptional game that is gushing with style, foreboding atmosphere and unique gameplay. Thumper looks like an animated version of M.C. Escher's mathmetical collection of paintings that were drowned in a futuristic hellscape. The simplicity of the graphics is frequently overlooked as you're dazzled with a myriad a blazing light shows and particle explosions as you race down the runway with no intention of stopping. I was especially impressed with the unique take on button presses for a music and rhythm game. You'll find yourself holding down a face button while quickly pressing, and sometimes holding, a directional button in rapid succession in response to cues on the runway; The button presses feel visceral as they're translated to the onscreen action. Make no mistake, this game is also relentless with it's difficulty ramp. It starts out fairly simple with timed button presses and a single path along the runway, but it takes a bewildering nosedive the further you progress. And it's awesome. Checkpoints are generous and each level is broken up into two or more dozen sections that climax with a boss encounter. Getting an S rank on every section is a fantastic challenge, and with enough practice you embrace the cacophonous percussion, entering a Zen-like state with perfectly timed button presses. The addition of VR makes the atmosphere and sense of scale appreciably more intense, and it's my preferred way to play this game--but certainly not required--as the game is excellent without VR. Buy this game.

28576390.review:
Frustration. That's what I feel the most when I play the later levels of Thumper. Missing a turn I previously got on another attempt, reset. Miss a thump, reset. In ways, the game feels like something I would have given up on ages ago.

Maybe it's the crazy soundtrack that assaults your ears, maybe it's the visuals, maybe it's the fact that this game manages to capture the feeling of satisfaction so well. Whatever it is, I'm glad Thumper has managed to work its magic.

This is the type of game that wins rewards and reviews well, but its fairly milquetoast unless you're dying for a rez-like driver, but without all the creativity and weirdness of the original Rez game.  This is definitely a fun and interesting game but ultimately could really have used more models and textures and more general weirdness.  Even in its current form, its worth recommending, but it helps to ignore the hype and keep expectations reasonable. I went in with pretty high expectations from all the hype and was somewhat disappointed, but its still a good and fun game, just not a great game.

From a gameplay perspective, its fairly twitchy and it hits difficulty ramps quickly. 1-13 took me 4 or 5 attempts when 1-1 to 1-12 were very easy for me.  I also had a little trouble understanding what the controls on the screen meant. "R" isn't press right, its trigger on the right Vive controller, for example. The game also started behind me when I launched it which took a minute to figure out, so I may have missed some intro elements. Games starting behind you or displaying critical text off screen in VR is inexcuable  this late in the game. Not sure why this is still an issue with some games.  

I am anxious for someone to get this genre right in VR. I imagine if the dev group that made this had 2x the budget and 2x the time they could have really filled it out more.  As-is its kinda thin. Not bad for a Jeff Minter inspiried  space driver.

28563402.review: Better than it looks, and it looks pretty good. If you're interested in getting it, you'll probably love it and get hooked in a minute. It's aiming to be something, and it definitely succeeds at it. More than just a simple game, it's a psychedelic trip gone right. The music is pretty catchy, groovy with a tribal/ambient feel to it, which is a nice change from all these melodies you get in similar games, though it could use some variety. The controls aren't too simple, not too complex either, but still pretty intuitive, with a quick and pleasant learning curve through a subtle "tutorial". This game is fast, intense and challenging, yet not frustratingly hard or "trial and error", and forgiving enough (properly synced as you would expect from such game aswell). Everything is balanced in the oh so right ammount, and it's a breath of fresh air among typical video games. Graphics and the art are also pretty cool, plus, they do not require an overkill gaming PC. The gameplay, the patterns and sound effects feel really good, it's just immensely satisfying. Thumper has it all and is perfectly designed, you don't get that feeling of terrible repetitiveness many games like those leave you with pretty quickly. My biggest complaints would be the lack of variety in the music and the ammount of levels, which isn't a flaw per se, but it does leave you wanting more because it is that good. Still, not overly short either, and it's understandable that a level would take time to make. Thumper is a solid 9/10

28539056.review:
I don't think Thumper is a bad game, but there are some core mechanics that I don't necessarily agree with:

1) Thumper uses auditory cues to tell the player what "notes" are coming up and uses visual cues to indicate when to play those notes. In my opinion, this causes the game to feel somewhat "out-of-sync".
2) The sound effects when you hit/miss the notes are way too loud and masks the visual cues of future notes.
3) The slow-down effect when you mess up and lose your outer shell breaks the flow of the rhythm.

It's certainly a very pretty looking game and I can understand its appeal, but I don't think it's the rhythm game for me.

28497720.review:
Well, let's start with the good stuff. Thumper is one of the most intense and beautiful games I've ever played. It's got fantastic art direction; the graphics make it look like you're traveling between universes, and combined with the music it creates an incredibly tense atmosphere as if some kind of eldritch beast might jump out at you at any moment. My personal favorite part are the bosses: their design is often so incredibly weird and unique (ranging from the giant head forecast in the trailers to what appear to be sentient wormholes) that it makes me want to see more. 


So what's bad about this game? In short: the gameplay. 

I haven't played many other rhythm games, so I can't exactly compare, but I found that this game became damn near impossible around level 4. Specifically, the final boss of said level. In the levels leading up to it, I could [i]eventually[/i] beat them by meticulously memorizing the pattern over the course of fifteen minutes and ignoring most of the obstacles. That isn't an option in the boss levels. Combine that with the nearly split-second timing required to hit some of the panels and the fact that, because of a bafflingly bad gameplay decision by the programmers, you're not allowed to switch rails while holding the space bar, and by the end of level 4 the game has become, as far as I'm concerned, borderline unplayable. If it weren't for the existence of footage of people beating the later levels, I'd accuse this game of being literally unbeatable, especially since it appears to continue scaling in difficulty at the same rate. And that's a shame, because the atmosphere and music are spot on; this is an absolutely fantastic game in every area [i]except[/i] the gameplay. 

tl;dr version: If you have the free time, look up a walkthrough of this game. I guarantee you'll enjoy it. But don't waste twenty dollars on the game itself. It's not worth the rage you'll experience trying to beat it.

28458715.review:
An attempt to make music-based games something other than audiosurf, and something more inspired than DDR, Thumper is a game about a metal beast of sorts. Could be an isopod with wings, could be a sci-fi bullet, or it could be a scarab, but whatever it happens to be, it loves its hotwheels track, and prefers to stick to it.

Controls are hyper simple and the game doesn't lie to you when it claims that the controls are 'a button and a stick. Because of that and as it goes, they can crank up difficulty by having some curves tossed in. Yes these curves and and will kill you, and as such, this forces you pay attention only to the track itself, so that you can not die long enough to die to the boss, which is a crying shame since the world around you is a living thing with pulsating shapes and colors, not dissimilar to your friend on news years eve at 9 PM. 

The bosses, as well as foes in general, are cut and dry basic geometric shapes with what appears to be tenticles to at least some degree, but they merely exist for show. You damage yourself, rest assured. The bosses and other foes puke up the hotwheels track you exist on, and present you times to damage them, but not before throwing in a curve or two, or some toothpicks for you to dodge under. If you fail to press the button at each 'damage time', however, the entire course will reset. Again, keeps it predictible which isn't a bad thing, but after a while it stops being a pleasure and starts being some mumbling about that toothpick that keeps killing you.

All damage periods, and curves corralate to the beat of the music more or less, and said beat can only be best appricated with a pair of bass boosting headphones, of which I do not own; because the beat has to resonate, and replace your heart beat, so when you force your metal thing to die, you will too, but in real life, and only once.

The game is unforgiving and yet checkpoints are aptly placed; just enough to force you to try, but not so few that dying is a major set-back. Its quite rewarding to get everything right the first time, and its entertaining to see that triangle writhe in pain as you fling green balls of bile deep into the center of it. 

It just gets irriating fast, I'm afraid. Naturally if you die on a set of track, the track doesn't change, so the game remains predictible in that way, and after hearing the same few sets of the same electronic song, it merely gets old. 5 years a second old. 

I'll be continuing this one.

8/10

28407588.review:
[b]edit: HOLY CRAP it looks jawdropping with my Vive!!![/b]

I really like Thumper, it's an amazing and intense game, but you shouldn't buy it expecting a game like Guitar Hero or Rock Band. It's not a rhythm or music game in that sense, it has a much heavier emphasis on fast reflexes. The player character (the beetle) should usually be thought of as playing an accompanying instrument, not directly matching the background music. [i]This isn't a problem with the game, it's just important to have the right expectations before buying.[/i]

If you're having a hard time, here are some pointers:

- Don't aim for high scores the first time you play a level, you'll probably just get frustrated. After playing later levels your reflexes and instinct will have become so sharp that you'll be able to come back to earlier levels and ace them without any need for memorization or restarting.

- Turn up your speakers/headphones. This will allow you to better hear the audio cues that come in advance of many obstacles, especially corners.  It also helps makes the game even more enthralling and gets you into its rhythm.

- As far as I've played in the game, there have [b]never[/b] been two turns the same direction in quick succession (within a half second or less). It's always Left-Right or Right-Left, never Left-Left or Right-Right. If you see a turn in one direction, be prepared to turn the opposite direction immediately after. I also haven't seen an obstacle aside from turns that require you to hold A+Left or A+Right, so there's probably no harm in just immediately holding the opposite direction after completing a turn to be sure you aren't surprised.

- Once you get good at jumping/flying and landing, this is often a much faster way of hitting beats that come in quick succession compared to just hitting A as fast as you can. Later in the game (level 5) it's virtually impossible to hit every beat without using this technique.
