Get Thumper!
Thumper is a unique rhythm game, because it's not actually a rhythm game. How? Rhythm games, like Audiosurf and Geometry Dash, follow a specific pattern to follow a soundtrack or song. In Thumper this is not the case. Thumpers soundtrack (DLC) is only a base of the beat YOU have to create. Another difference is the the fact that this game is pretty violent. Not by blood and gore, but by the sheer intensity this game has. The beat definitely has an "oomph" to it. It sounds like you're going into battle with a war drum on your chest! 

For anyone who likes these types of games, this is for you. But be warned though. This game can be raging, but since the tutorial is well laid out and gives you time to master the basic skills, you'll fling through the levels in no time! But, of course, the developers know this, and the levels they made will test not only your skills, but also your reflexes. What I'm saying here is that Thumper can be healthy for you, because by the time you finish the game, your reflexes will be a lot faster, since everything happens so fast.

You will never regret getting this game!

28231330.review:
This game will make your brain melt and your heart thump. I imagine this game will be more favorable to you if you are musician with fairly decent background, as the game moves VERY quickly and if you don't anticipate the rhythms in odd sections (offbeats, leading beats, complex meters) by eventually catching on to the pattern, it will feel somewhat random.

Gameplay/challenge: This game will best suit you if you're a fan of hard games as this game is VERY challenging and beyond that has an EXTREMELY high skill cap if you are going for a high score. That said, the game is fairly well designed and will teach you new techniques and patterns in isolation before mixing it in with other stuff. Checkpoints are typically frequent, so you will slowly progress if you keep trying, although you will certainly not hit any great grades if you do this without trying to master each segment.

Music: But seriously, get this game. The soundtrack is very intense and has a great weight to it. Stylistically, think of it as playing a whole rhythm game where the soundtrack is pulled from Invader Zim industrial background music with a modern twist. The sound effects when you properly hit notes just *feel* powerful, and you'll find yourself pressing the controller and stick much harder than you probably need to on occasion as a result of its weighty feel.

Visuals: This game is BEAUTIFUL and visually is one of the most impressive I've ever seen. Seriously, just look at any of the screenshots. The game looks like that ALL the TIME but with nonstop motion added and constantly shifting colors. It feels like a drug trip without drugs and tends to intersperce calm sections where you just appreciate the scenery with the brutal sequences of rhythm.

TLDR: High challenge/skill cap for perfectionists/twitch games, mind-boggling visuals, gripping gameplay with an equally gripping industrial Zim-esque rhythm soundtrack, bonuses for trained musicians who like mixed meter. If any of these things seem appealing to you, do yourself a favor and take yourself on a trip with this game.

28198653.review:
I only just found out about this game when it released. Saw a few videos and had to get it.

I'm a musician, and instructor. Have been playin music for most my life and this game kicked my butt. 

There's parts of each level that groove and feel "right" while a lot of the rest of the level doesn't seem to fit with the tempo/time signature, (each level number represents it's time signature). It frustrated me a LOT. I felt like the devs put in those groove sections to make it seem like a rhythm game but most the filler was just an out of time mess.

I was wrong.

The more you learn about the mechanics, which are actually fairly complex for one button and stick, the more you'll apreciate how finely tuned this game is. So, a lot of the patterns don't exactly groove like typical rhythm games, but once you start feeling how all the more advanced scoring mechanics work together, you'll start feeling the music in really interesting ways.  It's hard to explain, haha.

Yes.... your thumbs will get sore playing this, like... seriously. But man.... when you nail sections and feel how it all fits together there's no comparison to how awesome it makes you feel.  

There's PLENTY of replay that can be had in this, plus the music will stick with you and make you want to play more just to hear it again.

It's worth the price.

28192389.review: A remarkably focused piece of game design. The product of seven years spent honing five basic inputs, paring away the unnecesary to reveal the essential. Tense and trance-inducing, abstract and visceral. Thumper appears as an alien artifact from a parallel dimension, its bass-heavy beat the echo of an exploded world where game design evolved after its own internal logic rather than mimicing more established media. No uncanny mimesis, no turgid diegesis. Just flowing challenge. Thumper is a sickening antidote to the ills of an increasingly directionless medium, painful pennance for the sins of an industry gone astray. Buy this game.

thumper is a (very fast paced) rhythm game in which the player assumes the role of some sort of futuristic space beetle, perenially running through various tracks of exquisite, colorful, psychedelic beauty.

despite the extreme simplicity of its control scheme (you will only use the analog stick and one button), it features a considerable amount of game mechanics (which include, but are not limited to, hitting notes (obviously), jumping over obstacles, flying through rings and bursting through barriers) (note: some of the latter ones are missing a tutorial at the beggining of the level, which makes them unnecessarily hard to grasp and makes the game a little more frustrating than it should be).

not the kindest or most gentle of masters (although it did become more forgiving of players' mistakes, especially those going for the s rank, by allowing one to replay the previous checkpoint, something which was not possible when the game released), thumper won't really take you by your hand and proceed to calmly guide you through its many obstacles and thrills: it will, instead, grab you by your wrist and speed ahead, not very concerned if you are able to keep up, occasionally slapping you in the face. stick with it, however, and you will start doing things you likely didn't think yourself capable of. and it will be amazing.

28108768.review:
I had been hyping myself up for Thumper since spring and can safely say it lived up to the hype, it's an [b]outstanding[/b] game and even after all my hyping, it still managed to exceed my expectations!

The gameplay is the most unique I've played this year, it's unlike any other rhythm game I have played. I expected something similar to Audiosurf, but that assumption was blown out of the water when I played the first level. One button and one stick sends your chrome-clad space beetle on its way careering down its metal track into the unknown whilst encountering harsh conditions along the way. You get a sense that you will never know what will appear next in the game due to the different rhythms that will batter you, and it will always keep you on your toes.

It goes without saying, but with a tagline of "rhythm-violence", this game is hard. It's going to force you into a sense of rhythm and will make you good at the game, whether that means dying countless times. At the end of each level you'll have a massive head looming over you, throwing beats your way hoping to kill you in the process unless you smash the four glows without error. Getting them all and delivering a supercharged shockwave towards the demonic head gives you the sense that you perfected the level, just like getting all the notes right on an instrument. But knowing once you get good at Thumper, and that you can perfect that one level you had trouble with ages ago with ease, just like perfecting a piece of music, you feel that nothing the game can throw at you will stand in your way. 

Visuaully, it's astounding for such a limited-ish game: my little space bettle shining in its full glory down the track (with no video settings at that) adds to the simplicity of the game comprised of a long metal track, a massive circle unforgiving of your mess-ups and the right-angled turns make for a simplistic but nonetheless aesthetically pleasing visual style.

The sound design in this game is quite simply untouched. The soundtrack is extremely unique with higher levels composed of their respective time signatures, so level 5 is 5:4 and level 7 is 7:4. It really does spice up the gameplay making you consider the different rhythms that will come later in the game. With a vast array of elements like audio cues, bassy thumps and the squeaky clank on a perfect turn, it makes for a flawless augmentation onto the science fiction-esque OST.

With the addition of the Play+ mode, it has kept me on edge every single time with the sense of annihalation if you slip up twice. No going back. I managed to complete Level 8+ in one sitting without dying, and it was the most heart pounding moment of this game yet. Knowing that I could die at any given moment after being stripped of my chrome armour, getting especially tense during the appearance of the "Ring of Death" hoping to tear you apart on any miss on multiple lanes. Horror games can boast their jump-scares and scary monsters in the dark, but can't compare to Thumper's bleak, glooming atmosphere and the sense of not knowing what's coming next.

There are only one or two cons I feel I should mention. 

Sometimes, the beats that the game throws at you can be extremely unexpected and often land on the off-beat of the music, which can make it difficult to get into a real flow of the game. This mostly happens in levels 5, 6, 7 and 9 where the game speeds up and gives you less time to think about the music and make it more about quick reaction. However, these levels have irregular time signatures so that may be a factor. 

It's got a slightly high price (£15.99) , which is pretty uncommon for an indie single-player game. I would have expected a price closer to £11.99 because there are many other games which offer more content at a lower price, but the game is still definitely worth it at £15.99 and has offered me close to and imminently upward of 40 hours with the score-attack replayability of its levels.

Straight recommendation. The best game I've played of 2016.

28107440.review:
You are a beetle careening down a track at breakneck speeds. Ahead of you are a series of glowing lights on the track, followed by several consecutive curves, more glowing lights, floating rings, translucent tendrils, then more glowing lights. Boom. Boom. Boom. Ching. Ching. Ching. BoomBoom. Schick. BRAAAHHHH. Boom Boom. The beat perfectly complements the hellish music which accompanies you on your seemingly endless journey through the depths of interdimensional cosmic hell.
 
A smile emerges on your face as you feel a shiver go down your spine. Awestruck and wanting more, your knuckles go white as the next series of glowing lights approach.
 
The gist of the game is fairly simple: as you travel down the track, you must hit a button in line with the lights on the ground, and occasionally you lean/move in a given direction when appropriate. The stages start out simply enough in the beginning, with new mechanics like flying, multiple lanes, and oncoming enemies being introduced every so often. The difficulty rises gradually over the course of the first 3 levels, but then takes a sharp spike upwards at around level 4, where the increasing speed and introduction of new mechanics begin to take their toll. It can be frustrating. But each failed attempt brings you closer and closer to finishing a stage, which serves as a teacher that prepares you for the iterative mechanics of each subsequent stage.
 
Although punishing, Thumper becomes increasingly rewarding with each level of mastery you attain. The ranking system is simple enough, with “S” ranks being essentially perfect runs, “A” ranks being great runs, and so on. However, the skill ceiling seems to be so absurdly high that, at a certain point, even an “S” rank doesn’t necessarily feel good enough. There’s always a turn that could’ve been executed better. There’s always a series of beats that could be more rhythmically pleasing. Thumper has a surprisingly effective carrot-on-a-stick that extends the replay value almost indefinitely as you strive to get a “Perfect” on every turn and rack up the multiplier while simultaneously crafting a beat that sends a feeling of frisson down your spine.
 
Part of what makes Thumper so great is the fact that you aren’t just playing along with the music, in most cases you are actively contributing to it.
 
As a fan of the “Noise rock” band Lightning Bolt I may be a little biased, but Thumper’s soundtrack is phenomenal. Created by Lightning Bolt’s Brian Gibson, it is a cacophony of sound that engulfs you in its unsettling embrace of booming drums, shrill screams, and foreboding drawn-out soundscapes. It’s something that works in unison with the gameplay so well that the development process and unification of the gameplay and audio seems deserving of a documentary in and of itself. Text on a page doesn’t do it enough justice.
 
Visually, Thumper is nothing short of impressive.
 
The track you find yourself on loops back and forth, ascending and descending through what can best be described as interdimensional space. Flurries of lights, sparks, and other post-processing effects explode from your cute little beetle as you interact with every beat and curve. If that wasn’t enough, mastering mechanics makes things even more overstimulating. If executed properly, a flight-beat followed by a down-beat combo will shoot a ball of light that travels ahead of you down the track, illuminating other beats, killing tendrils, and creating the illusion that it created the track’s curves up ahead. Chaining these sorts of combos together multiple times is easily the most overstimulating and satisfying experiences you can have in any game. Objectively.
 
Despite not being a fan of other rhythm games, Thumper has been the single greatest unification of music and gameplay that I have ever experienced. It’s frustrating and difficult, but in a way that drives me toward perfection. It’s overstimulating and chaotic, but in a way that induces a trance-like state. It’s chaotic and violent, but in a way that shoots a cosmic beetle through the mouth of a fiery hell-skull. Thumper is amazing, and it’s something that deserves to be experienced as a whole. In all of its unsettling, heart-pounding glory.

(http://www.shatteredjoystick.com/single-post/2016/10/28/Thumper-PC--Review)

28104755.review:
So, now that I finally S ranked all the levels, I think I'm qualified to leave a review. Although I'll [i]try[/i] to be unbiased.
As a side note, I play rhythm games a LOT. I'm nowhere near the best, but definitely not the worst.

In short, if you rhythm games and twitchy gameplay, you should get this game. However, I would only recommend the full price ($20 USD) if you see yourself going through and perfecting the levels, as it is only 9 levels. Otherwise, wait till it goes on sale, even if for $15.

Now for a little more depth.
Visuals:
OH MAN. When they add VR support (as of November 30, it's been promised in a future update), I'm tempted to pick up a headset just for this game. It is BEAUTIFUL. The entire game looks like the screenshots, but even better. And since they made this game for PSVR, it is optimized to hell and back. For comparison, I've got a Radeon R7 370, and its running 1080p, 4x MSAA at a smooth 144 fps.

Audio:
I'm suprised I haven't gone deaf playing this game. I just keep turning it up louder and louder to get enveloped by it. And the soundtrack starts out so simple, but by the end, you are being borderline assaulted by noise, and it's everything I could ever want. But that's just cause I love the tribal feeling. It's very high quality. The composer knows exactly what he's doing.

Gameplay:
Okay, so this is where everyone seems to be torn. The problem is, I wouldn't necessarily call it a rhythm game. More like an [in]finite runner where all the obstacles happen to be on beat. Sure, it is "call and response", but towards the end, everything becomes so chaotic, you can't really hear the "call" anymore, and you have to rely on sight. Which is also hard, seeing how fast-paced it gets, and how it starts hiding things behind corners.
Anyway, I would liken the feeling towards being in the rhythm section of a band. You gotta keep the beat and listen for what's coming next, but be ready for anything. You get in the zone, and feel what's coming next.

All in all, this is an amazing game, that's hard to pin down. I was a little sad about the length, however with the PLAY+ update, I've got much more reason to keep playing and keep perfecting. I would definitely suggest trying before buying, unless you know you like these kind of mechanics.

个人很感兴趣这款游戏很久了，于是入了手顺便写篇评测：
1，建议手残党不要入，虽然是款音游，但对机会把握得很准，不然可能在关卡二就得崩溃。
2，建议有强迫症的也别急着买…因为这款游戏每大关卡有分各个小段，并且通关会评分S、A、B、C，这个对我这种分数强迫症是很折磨人的，于是你会开始刷每个阶段都是S，遇到难的关卡更是要死要活的度过几个小时，我就是因为刷S导致对游戏本身的兴趣下降了，一味看重分数玩着真的很累。如果是休闲娱乐没有负担的话可以玩，很刺激。
3，游戏的音乐可以说是魔性，和其他音游一样是以节拍来按按键，玩家扮演一只甲虫，每次只能允许一次失误，撞到了便会碎掉外甲，配上打击乐更是增添了紧张感，通关或者boss关卡会有个回复外甲的区域。
4，速度感很强，玩的时候别一段一段停着玩，注意！！！！这款游戏只有长时间击打正确并连续玩才是最爽的！这也是这款游戏的主心骨，所以玩的时候可以先别考虑评分，通关了再玩一遍追求评分也不急，不然游戏体验也大打折扣。
总结就是会玩的肯定停不下来，有种电子海洛因的感觉，不过玩久了也有点审美疲劳了。。。
ps：我是用ps4手柄玩的，个人建议还是猛敲空格吧

27856894.review:
This game sends shivers down my spine, it's really great!
Thumper is a rhytm game based on sound AND visuals.

You must follow the rhytm pattern by repeating a sound sequence (for things that aren't visible from distance and appear), and at the same time be ready to react to obstacles visible from afar.

Some people find this game not very rhytm based because of the chaos, but that's what I like about Thumper the most - finding a pattern in adrenaline rush, when you hear and watch closely.

As you progress through game you learn new tricks that can be used in earlier levels to earn more points - those tricks were there all the time, you just didn't know about them (no need to "unlock" them). So I recommend to play a bit instead of trying to complete it all S from the start.

I've been watching this game for over a year and I'm not dissapointed with end product :) Recommended!
If you are curious about early stages of the game there is some footage on their YouTube channel, guys did a great job on this game.

27674174.review:
Thumper is an insanely intense rhythm game sort of in the vein of Frequency (PS2) or Audiosurf. "Rhythm violence" is a very apt description - thumps and turns have a brutal physicality to them that you don't often find in games. It just [i]feels[/i] good to play. This is the kind of game where blinking can have devastating consequences, and successfully completion a section will produce an audible sigh of relief. 

It departs from typical rhythm games in that it's not really based around "songs" so much as a call-and-response system, focusing more on reaction time and twitch reflexes. Although I probably won't be listening to the soundtrack too often, the music/sound effects are brilliantly designed and really add to the physicality of each action, and helps create the psychedelic musical hellscape that is the hallmark of the game.

The game ramps up in difficulty as you progress through it's 9 lengthy courses, but thanks in part to its generous checkpoints it never gets too frustrating. The difficult part is then trying to perfect your play and climb the online leaderboards, especially in the recently added "Play+" mode which is even faster and has no checkpoints.

Thumper is one of the most intense games I've ever played in my life. It will melt your face off and leave your thumbs blistered and I loved every minute of it.

27086380.review:
Thumper is a game that should have been perfect for me. I'm a musician focused on drums, I love drones and dark ambient, I love the demoscene, I loved guitar hero, I love bullet hell shooters and masochistic difficulties, the list of reasons I should love this game just goes on and on. But I really don't.

Instead, Thumper is a slog to play that deals less with rhythmicality than rote memorisation. It goes out of its way to screw with any accumulated sense of rhythm over levels that take far too long to complete to ever want to return to (upwards of 15 minutes each). 

A gimmick of the engine is that every successful interaction the player has with the game triggers percussion, which means if your rhythm is off, the triggered sound is off too. The background audio functions as a sort of metronome intended to give you something to correct to, but the audio mix reduces that beat to a noisy growl under the din of your own off-center beats, meaning as levels increase in intensity your own off-ness creeps into your entire performance: Since the beats sound "right" to you but are in fact off by some margin, you slowly but surely creep closer to the offset where the game determines you straight up missed it. Among the reliable beats are the turns (which go off when they must as opposed to when you turn), but the levels of syncopation and sections of silence mean they are about as useful as a person next to you randomly bumping into you as you play. It's just maddening.

Thumper at its highest intensity (if you're not counting the endless rinse-repeat memorisation of drilling down a checkpoint until you perfect it) boils down to reading audio tells, but again the audio mix fails it. The thing about such a noisy soundscape is you run out of room to communicate with subtlety in the high frequencies. I never got comfortable with the tells for the elevated notches for instance (I was surprised to find out they even have one), and the game frequently sends you through turning and twisting tunnels depriving you of any visual tell to go by. No audio mix options to tweak the game to your own system exacerbate this.

The biggest failure of the game, IMO, is in its inability to build and sustain a rhythm, opting instead to give you frequent bouts of silence and random bouts of syncopation. It doesn't matter if you've a looping drum roll going in the background if the actual beats you have to hit on top of that are so haphazardly placed you are almost never allowed to "get into it". Add to this the game's love of animations and audio cues that don't have bearing on the rhythm whatsoever (the beetle hop when you release the boost is a constant annoyance for me) as well as frequent messing with time (recovering from a collision and other slowmo) all go into removing any pleasure I could get from what could otherwise be a pounding and satisfying drum session. Instead levels on first encounter are 15-20 minute grinds followed by further grinding checkpoint by checkpoint to build "mastery" that really just comes down to remembering patterns. It just goes on and on and even at its best I don't think it's rewarding my time. Halfway through *level 5* I was just exhausted. No thanks.

Thumper is too long, too repetitive, too random, poorly mixed, with a confounding scoring system. When Drool called this Rhythm Violence, irritating the player to the point of needing to punch a pillow wasn't what I thought they had in mind.

26912837.review:
I've played many rhythm games. osu!, soundodger+, bit+trip, and thumper. All of these rhythm games, excluding Thumper, use the background music and rhythm to build the game. I'm not saying I hate any of the mentioned games. osu! is a great rhythm clicker and aim-practice-er... ehrm.. soundodger has stood the test of time for me in the dodge-rhythm genre, and bit+trip is a great rhythmic platformer.

One thing that separates Thumper from these other games is the way it handles rhythm. The song provides minimal support of rhythm to go through the levels. [b] You[/b] are making the rhythm as you go along. This is what makes Thumper so incredible to play.

One other thing is that Thumper's controls, while simple at heart, get ever more complex with rising speed and different combos to pull off. It's a fantastic rhythm game that is worth the money to anyone who loves rhythm games.

26870667.review:
https://niveloculto.com/analisis-thumper/

La pista de infinita de Thumper brilla entre explosiones psicodélicas mientras nosotros, un escarabajo plateado, avanzamos a trompicones a través de un universo cercano a la concepción que un Peter Gabriel en los noventa muy puesto de LO MULTIMEDIA tendría del infierno. Bajo esa apariencia inmaculada, donde la suciedad no existe y la música solo insinúa, se nos pide alcanzar un estado de sinestesia, que asimilemos, aunque solo sea un instante, el total de lo que allí se nos ofrece. La diferencia, la gran diferencia de Thumper con propuestas similares, es que al alcanzar el nirvana a través del flow que genera cada uno de sus elementos, no encontramos una apacible sensación de tranquilidad, sino que nos asomamos a un abismo mucho mayor del que insinúa esa pista de la que no podemos escapar.

He tenido que pasar varias horas con Thumper para entender las razones por la que desde Drool lo anunciaban como un título de violencia rítmica. Tras este periodo no creo poder dar una explicación exacta, pero les puedo asegurar que he pasado, al menos, tanto tiempo pensando en Thumper como jugando con él. Buena parte de esto creo que tiene que ver con su envoltorio, no ya estético, sino mecánico. Hemos pasado ya por las suficientes pistas infinitas llenas de ritmo como para bajar la guardia ante una propuesta similar. Yo ya he estado ahí y sé lo que esperar. Dame música y elementos que vengan en mi dirección que ya me ocuparé yo de mejorar lo suficiente como para que al darle al botón adecuado todo encaje. Thumper es eso, o al menos lo es de una manera que no puedo calificar de otro modo que abyecta. Hay algo incómodo en cada pulsación. Puede que se deba a que no hay un ritmo claro, que vaya desde el juego hacia el jugador, sino que en cierta manera lo va creando el propio jugador por sí mismo. Este cambio, de experiencia diegética a extradiegética, mantiene el permio entre los reflejos y la capacidad de predecir el siguiente movimiento, pero añade un elemento de ansiedad de que va más allá de no acertar en el momento correcto con la pulsación exacta, pues requiere un reaprendizaje constante de las reglas de este extraño universo.

La otra pata sobre la que crece esta violencia rítmica es la representación de nuestras acciones dentro del título, pues realizar correctamente cada una de las combinaciones no obtendremos una respuesta emocional tranquilizadora, sino cargada de intensidad, la cual se siente a veces casi como una agresión a la propia representación de Thumper. No es por tanto la clásica representación de una prueba de habilidad que en base a nuestra pericia nos termine otorgando una puntuación más o menos alta, aunque esto también se encuentre aquí, sino que el concepto de juego rítmico deriva en un título de supervivencia en el que nunca tendremos muy claro si somos nosotros los que estamos sobreviviendo al universo de Thumper o él a nosotros.

La confianza de Drool en su propuesta y sus ganas de realizar un título que escape a los cánones del género tiene su máxima representación en la selección musical elegida. Antes de poner mis manos sobre el juego me preguntaba por qué tratándose de un título rítmico se estaba hablando tan poco de la música de Thumper. No sabía si sería posible incluir un listado externo o descargar nuevas pistas. En definitiva, buscaba otro Audiosurf con un escarabajo metalizado. La respuesta te la da el propio juego, pues la banda sonora se construye a través de una partitura que va modificándose, acortándose y alargándose según avanzamos. Una tormenta industrial que no teme descargar su ira a base de sintetizadores o moverse en una calma tensa que mí, al menos por momentos, me ha recordado a un Vangelis de bajona.

Lo demás es arcade del bueno. Del jodido. Del de “vamos a parar un rato porque quizás acabe reventando el mando contra la pared y esto vale un dinero”. Hay decenas de obstáculos, cada cual más envenenado que el anterior. Hay enemigos, por supuesto. Enemigos que atacan y a los cuales únicamente puedes golpear con una bolita que sale después de haber realizado una serie de combinaciones perfectas que pueden acabar con la paciencia de más de uno. Hay una curva de dificultad perfectamente medida para que creas que siempre te encuentras el borde del desastre, pero sin embargo avanzas un pasito más, y otro. La recompensa es más música, más violencia, más sentirte incómodo mientras lo disfrutas a demasiados niveles como para intentar explicarlo.

Thumper es sencillamente el mejor juego musical al que he jugado nunca. Lo es porque ha conseguido que dentro del género no me haya sentido como una cobaya que tenía que pulsar el botón rojo en el momento que se me indica para ganarme mi recompensa. Soy consciente de que eso es exactamente lo que hace, pero con la diferencia de que en esta ocasión tengo la sensación de que el ritmo me pertenece, que puedo hacer algo más que salivar cuando el científico de turno toque el silbato, como por ejemplo arrancarle la mano.

26639443.review:
Thumper has the simplest controls I've seen in a game of this caliber (just the A button and the joystick; you could theoretically play this on an Atari 2600 controller) but it has so many mechanics working in tandem that it's very easy to forget that fact. I love this game because of it, but my thumbs think otherwise.

Also, this game makes you feel like a god when you land a combo on a particularly difficult level; it's a feeling not many other games can replicate. I'm not even that good at the game and I feel like a god at it. That's how to make a good game.

26636636.review: "I have never felt the urge to rate a game on steam." is a sentence I can no longer use. Everything has been said about this game already. Except: Batman Jones loves this game as well.

26616612.review:
Extremely good game, definitely recommend. 
It might be a couple of dollars steep. (12 hours for me to complete the game, roughly.) However, the game does offer a more challenging "+ Playthrough" if you are content with not beating your high scores.

- Very difficult game. The game trains you well and starts slow but, due to it's fast pace and execution, after a certain point in the game every stage is capable of challenging you. On subsequent playthoughs it won't be as bad because you will develop your muscle memory, but it is especially brutal for a Thumper virgin. Brutal but, very satisfying.

- Beautiful visuals. I decided to play this game after only seeing about 30 seconds worth of footage through a stream. Exquisite colors and effects bombard your eyeballs as you desperately try and keep your beetle alive through his LSD-esque adventure through space.

- Sound Design. Excellent sound. However, you might need a good headset or speaker system to make full effect of this. Thumper is a ryhthym game, and using your eyes is incredibly helpful at certain points in the game. At times you might find yourself blinded by the acid trip, and being able to discern what sounds are what DOES make a difference. 
DON'T RELY ON YOUR EYES TOO MUCH.

- Execution. You don't need to hit every obstacle to earn a good rating but, dropping a combo will hurt you. There are lots of little mechanics that require tight timing, though they aren't necessary for completion. For the most part you have a choice of whether to avoid *some* things, or to put yourself in danger for a big point bonus.

---

CONS: There are not really many actual problems with this game so they can likely all fit in 1 or 2 sentences.

- Sensory Overload. Sometimes you just won't be able to keep up with everything on screen. You need to keep your eyes open, ears primed, and fingers dancing. You may be blinded at one point, or unable to discern one sound from another, Or you can't execute everything, like hitting a hard combo in a fighting game.
- There is one aspect of the game that I'm still trying to figure out if it has a tell or not. Apart from visually discerning it at 100mph, lane switches are hard to see. That's about it.

I'm having some cognitive dissonance on whether or not to bash the game's difficulty in discerning sound, being a rhythym game. It can definitely be an annoying issue when considering how difficult the game can be. I'm going to leave it at this for now.

____
Now all we need are custom tracks!

26592640.review:
The core mechanics in this are really solid, and it's a great example of easy to learn and hard to master.  The controls are really simple (in fact, it could be played on an old Atari joystick if you were so inclined).  The game will tutorialize things pretty well and then mashes things together and complicates them as you go.

Pros:
Gorgeous
Great music
Love the audio cues before each thing (that fit with the music)

Cons (for some):
Can be visually tiring
Can be very demanding - will punish you if you're not there in the moment

Nitpicks:  
Had crashes changing resolution, then the game wouldn't start.  I deleted and redownloaded it and everything worked fine (including saved data).
The mechanic where 2 fast up+jumps make you stay in the air longer is not obvious.  If you are trying to get an S on 6-1 and can't get everything in the air, this is your problem.
Last 2 levels don't have the same feel as the rest of the game.  They aren't that hard though, so I can overlook it.  
The blocks with the green trails don't seem to behave differently than normal.  I'm still not sure what they're there for.

Overall I'm really happy with it.  I've 100%'d it (which is tough, as of right now only 0.4% have) and I'm actually a little sad as I'll not end up playing it much more.  Highly recommended.

I got Thumper because I love rhythm games and the game was described as such. The more I played the game, though, the more I realized how it evolved from its rhythm based premise to a pure trial-and-error experience which - to me - is a big disappointment. 

If I had to judge Thumper on the first 2 or 3 stages alone, I would give it a positive review. It features beautiful visual and sounds, everything about the game is captivating, the game mechanics work nicely and you really feeling 100% immersed in the game flow. Unfortunately this changes over time. The stages don't get more challanging, but just more unfair, with incredibly harsh sequences that the player cannot remotely foresee. The vibe of the game becomes monotonous, the rhythms fairly similar throughout the entire stage. 

Once again, if you come with the idea of getting a good rhythm game, I would probably not advise you to get Thumper. On the other hand, if you think that you will only play the first few stages and you are intrigued by its beautiful audio-visuals, go ahead and get it, don't even hesitate.

26347613.review:
Have you ever had something you just love but can't quite explain why? You try explaining it to your friends, but cant quite get across why its to excellent. This game is that for me.
It is without a doubt one of the best feeling games out there, it is incredibly tight, the controls are responsive, and everything works the way it should. The game only uses 2 inputs. the left analog stick, and a button (Use a controller, its way better), but the amount of complexity it manages with just those two inputs is staggering. Ill admit it starts off too slow, but after the first "Level" it ramps up beautifully. This is not a traditional rhythm game, the best way to describe it is a "call and response" system, credit to the other review I stole that off of. It matches to the beat, but isn't really a huge part of the song if that makes any sense. In fact that would be another gripe of mine, after the first couple levels the background music gets less interesting as it relies more heavily on you properly hitting the notes and beats. 
The game also ramps up difficulty very well, introducing not only new mechanics each levels but also speeding it up and limiting what you can see ahead of you through tunnels and such. You become less reliant on visual cues and more so on the actual sounds the game makes, which while they could be a bit louder clearly tell you whats coming. 
Overall I love this game and highly recommend it.

26342506.review:
Final Edit: I would like to make it clear that the biggest issue i have with the game is the audio cues. Its musical and Rhythm aspect. Everything else about this game really feels great, but the audio cues being faint and hard to hear makes this game frustrating to play, and any mistake i make, in most cases, feel like its the game not giving me any warning at all to whats coming up, and it feels cheap and unfair. I don't mind difficult, i just want fair difficulty, where it was my mistake that made me lose, not the game just throwing something at me out of nowhere with no warning and no time to react.
If you don't mind a more visual focused rhythm game, in which incredibly fast reactions or memorization is the main focus, with a little bit of rhythm mixing in, then definitely go for this game.
I just expected the game to be more fast paced Rhythm and visuals mixed together, not Visuals with just a bit of Rhythm too it. Read the rest of the review to know why i expected both a Rhythm and a Visual game mixed together, and why the game is clearly marketing itself for being both.

Many rhythm games don't need audio cues since you can easily see whats coming up next, and basing yourself on the rhythm and beat, you can play whats coming up correctly. Examples would be: DDR (you see the arrows and know the rhythm so you know how to play them) Amplitude (You can clearly see all the circles coming up and what rhythm and order you have to play them in), guitar hero/rock band (similar to amplitude, you can see the notes coming up and know the rhythm you need to play them in and what order)

This games visuals make it very difficult to see whats coming up next, and things just pop up infront of you and give you only about 1-2 seconds to react at best. As such the developpers added "Audio Cues" that tell you whats coming up to allow you to listen, hear the rhythm and beat and what you have to do, and then go with it. The problem is that the audio cues are too faint and hard to distinguished and so, many times you get caught because you cant hear/see what you have to do and get killed in a cheap annoying way. This ruins the "rhythm" aspect of the game, and instead you have to memorize certain parts of the tracks since its just easier then trying to listen to what you have to do. I have played a lot of rhythm games in the past, and this game is really close to beating all of them. It just needs this one little adjustement and it would be absolutely amazing. instead it just ends up being frustrating and cheap to play.
If the audio cues were better, this game would instantly be one of my favorite rhythm games of all time. And right now, it still kinda is a rhythm-music game, it just doesn't do the rhythm-music part right.

I don't want the game to be easier, i don't want the game to change its own style, its a fast paced rhythm violence game. The problem i have is that the audio cues just mix in TOO much with the music in the background. While the visuals outright block whats coming up, most notably, in the tunnel sections, leading to some very cheap and annoying deaths that can only be avoided by memorizing the track. I can hear the audio cues sometimes, i know what they are, but if its going to market itself as, and i quote:
"Thumper is rhythm violence: classic rhythm-action, blistering speed, and brutal physicality. "
(taken straight from the steam "About This Game" section,  "classic rhythm-action is clearly stated here, and in the description aswell.)
then i expect the rhythm part to also be a major part of the game, and for it to be consistently clear and important. Its definintely trying to be, its just not succeeding at it. 

The game also has the Rhythm and Music tags to it, so you can't tell me its not trying to also be a rhythm game. I know its trying to be a mix of rhythm and bullet hell style, where things come at you in large numbers and quickly, giving you little time to react, but rhythm games thrive on having easy visuals, but difficult rhythms that are still clear. bullet hells are good at having really clear visuals that are hard to avoid. This game fails at both.
But it comes very close to doing it right, if steam allowed neutral reviews i would give it one, but it doesn't.
In the end you CAN go with the rhythm, but only after you've memorized the tracks already. You can't use both your eyes and ears to know whats coming up and then do it perfectly everytime simply because you're that good at music and reacting. In this game, when you get stuck in a tunnel, the audio cues are faint and hard to hear, so you rely on your eyes, only for the game to throw two sudden walls when you couldn't possibly see the second wall until it was already too late. And if the audio cue was just a little bit more obvious then it would be purely up to the player to hear it, realise what he has to do, and then do it in the rhythm of the song.

I cannot hear the audio cues and so i cannot do the right actions to the rhythm of the game because the visuals block most of what you can see at times. And so, its clear the developpers wanted to add something to fix this issue, which is the audio cues ive mentioned many times. But these are too hard to hear, to difficult to distinguish in the song, and so everything falls apart, the visuals end up being distracting more then impressive, the difficulty becomes more cheap then challenging, and the music aspect becomes more reaction based then rhythm based. One small change could make everything i've just mentioned worked. And until that change to the audio cues is done, this review is gonna stay negative.

26316387.review:
I've never been a fan of rhythm games like Rock Band or Guitar Hero. Although I like music focused games, I don't think just putting a rhythm spreadsheed over existing written music can make an extraordinarily well designed game. And now here's Thumper, a game that looks, on the surface, a lot like Audiosurf, but at its core, it's something much, much different.

You're a beetle, riding down a lane with an ever increasing speed, having to dodge obstacles and trying to get combos by performing rhythmically accurate actions. It's so simple and yet so difficult. The difference to Audiosurf lies in the design of and the interplay between music and the levels. Everything is produced with the gameplay experience in mind. Levels build up on each other. Simply the fact that the time signature increases one beat per level shows how the developers intended to get a pacing into the game that could never be there with generative levels.

While I do think, Thumper hasn't realized its full potential and some improvements could have been included, I must say that I had tons of fun and even more tons of frustration just barely making it through the 9 levels alive. To me, this game is probably the best music game I have played since 140.

Highly recommended!

26282320.review:
TL;DR: If you're here for the rhythm aspect, I would stay away until an update fixes some things. If you're here for the high octane, "game-feel" defining gameplay,  and don't mind purely reaction-based stuff, this is your game.




I bought this game under the assumption that the focus of this game was rhythm. That's not the case, however. Where the game fails as a rhythm game, it succeeds as a reaction/memorization game. Though this game is SO frustratingly close to being an excellent rhythm game, there are a few details that keep it far from that title.


The visuals, while absolutely stunning, detract from the clarity of the game mechanics. Whenever you go through tunnels, the wall obstacles make the player turn a sharp corner, which prevents you from seeing obstacles that are around it. It also doesn't help when the color of the tunnel interior matches the orange glow of the wall; making it practically invisible. It cheapens the game's difficulty.


Absolutely none of that would be an issue if the audio cues that indicate which obstacles you'll have to avoid next were clear and distinct. They sadly aren't. They are unreasonably quiet, a fact that is painfully clear when the sound of dodging the current obstacle, plus the roaring tribal drums completely eclipse it. The cues also sound too similar to each other. When dozens of sound cues are constantly bombarding your ears, you need to be able to distinguish between them subconsciously. Vary the pitches, make the sounds have fundamentally different textures, anything you can to make them clear as crystal. The current system is simply too muddy to be useful at all.




All in all, if you like reaction-based "endless runner" style games and aren't afraid to do some track memorization for some of the S ranks, you'll really enjoy this game. This honestly may be one of the best "feeling" games I've ever played. Every time you clang into a turn or crash through a bar, it leaves a palpable and utterly satisfying impact. 


If you came here expecting a new rhythm game to grind at and master, you're gonna be disappointed. I really hope the devs touch up the game and really nail the little things, so you can play the game musically.  I can't help but feel a bit mislead by the "Rhythm Violence" tagline, as I don't feel it quite meets the standards of a  rhythm game. For me personally, it's not worth $20 in it's current state, that's the reason I refunded the game. I would be more than happy to re-purchase it when these issues are addressed or when the game goes on sale.


Thanks for reading. (I've said the word "rhythm" way too many times.)

26236839.review:
Pretty heafty on the price for the content, albeit still fun.

Plays well with keyboard and controller.

So, lets begin with the pros - a very interesting aproach to a rythm game which fully utilizes its one dimentional environment. The visuals are pretty nice, the space theme seems to suit this very well and reminds me of the original TapTap :). Adds lots of new obstacles as the game progresses, kepts it fresh.

Now, unfortunately the cons - the music is a bit too quite compared to the sound effects that you produce, in the first levels it isn't as noticable as in later levels where there are more obstacles. The music seems very very similar through out levels, and what slight variation there is gets masked by th esound effects. A lot of obstacle "combos" repeat, like "long left", "long right", "long left", "long right", these repeat on a lot of levels and get very predictable. Also the general route seems to be "left", "obstacles", "right", "obstacles", you rarely encounter more than 3 turns in the same direction in a row, so it is very predictable. Finally the thing I absolutely hate, why try to make a level harder by simply making it last ages? Also if you do intend in making harder levels longer, make them consisten, that is start with the shortest level and end with the longest (not counting "bosses", which are a very nice touch in my opinion). Seriousely, I currently just finished "world 6", and the fith last level (if I remember correctly) lasted a good minute, the next level over in 10-15 seconds. 

Overall it is a nice challenging game, the challenge curve was a little to small for my taste as I havent died once untill towards world 3 but enjoy the challenge that the game is presenting to me right now. I rate this as "recommended" as I enjoy the gameplay, the music is a HUGE let down, considering this is a music game but still. I would like the price to be somewhere around £8-9 at most £10.

26161557.review:
Я лучше скажу этого с самого начала: эта игра [b]безумно эпична.[/b]
Психоделическая атмосфера, которую лучше не пытаться понять, а просто погрузиться в неё. В этой ритм-игре, в отличие от [i]некоторых[/i], нету никакой техно-музыки, которую можно обычно услышать, скажем, в ночном клубе у диск-жокея. Нет. Музыка в этой игре - боевые барабаны вперемешку с сюрреалистичными звуковыми эффектами. И это без звука, который будет когда вы примётесь за прохождение этих уровней.

В игре всего 9 уровней, и может это покажется вам слишком коротким, но это не так. У меня 2 с половиной часа игры, и я только прошёл третий уровень! Кстати говоря, каждый уровень разделяется на этапы. В первом уровне, к примеру, 15 этапов, включая уровневого босса. Да, это не опечатка: [i]тут есть боссы.[/i] И они не менее безумные чем прочее в игре.
Так или иначе, эта игра сложная. С каждым уровнем требование к рефлексу становится выше и выше, первая половина предоставляет вам новые элементы игры, а во второй оставляет вас на произвол судьбы. И это не говоря уже о том, чтобы получить ранг S на каждом уровне!

Вобщем, вот вам плюсы и минусы этой игры.

[b][u]ПЛЮСЫ[/u][/b]
[list]
[*] Захватывающая атмосфера.
[*] Музыка
[*] Для нынешнего времени имеет вполне доступные системные требования.
[*] Простое управление
[*] Приличная по большей части сложность
[*] Боссы.
[*] Супер-жук.
[/list]
[b][u]МИНУСЫ[/u][/b]
[list]
[*] Главное меню и пауза ограничены в опциях, но я думаю разработчики это скоро исправят.
[*] Местами сложность резко поднимается, в половине случаев из-за того, что вы вряд ли сможете увидеть что будет дальше, прежде чем вы успеете среагировать. В этих случаях уже работает память.
[*] Все эти световые вспышки не очень хорошо помогают глазам.
[*] У тех, кто играет на клавиатуре, возможно будут болеть пальцы после игры. У геймпада тут существенное преимущество.[/list]

Кстати о геймпаде: я не знаю, точная информация или нет, но по-моему геймпады не работают на ПК-версии. Я могу ошибаться. По крайней мере у меня геймпад Defender Game Racer Turbo RS3, и он не работал.

Хм, ничего пропущено не было...?
...Ах да, сюжет! ...Если честно, то я не знаю. Я только знаю, что вы играете за жука, и вам нужно одолеть Кракхеда, и... мда.

Итог: Игра не для всех, но я очень рекомендую её опробовать. Цена в 420 рублей (или 20 долларов) того стоит.

26156132.review:
THUMPER - A pSycho-dellic rhythmic adrenaline fueled rollercoaster ride to hell.  

Now that I've 100% the game's achievements I feel that I have enough knowledge of the game to review it.  First and foremost, playtime & difficulty.  It took me 9 hours to beat the base game and took 9 more hours to complete all levels with an S rank.  For the majority of players it should take you beyond that much time and may even take some less than that time.  I don't recommend the game for casuals as you'll die in two hits, there are ways that the player may choose to make the game easier but can still be hard to beat.  

Next, the base game.  You'll boot up the game, choose the first level, get a quick tutorial of some of the basic and most important mechanics and will then start to get into some regular levels.  Even though most view a tutorial in games as bad I feel as if it's really important here since without it you may not be able to finish it and will get frustrated.  It's satisfying to hear the loud drum percussion of each wall, red bar, and blue ring and also provides the player a visual heads-up so they can plan their next move (as is with most rhythm games).  Each Level has a boss and an "Omega" final boss with sub-levels inbetween.  If you are struggling with a section it's always safe to hold spacebar and preemptively hold the arrow key of the wall that you're approaching, thump pads and red bars, and blue rings that appear on the track are optional and can be avoided in sub-levels.  However, the level boss and final boss have green thump pads which require you to hit each one in order to deal damage to the boss, if one is missed the level will loop until the player has either died or successfully hit every thump.  The final level is not only incredibly challenging and rewarding when you beat each section but also has one of the best endings of any games i've experienced this year, well worth the trip there.

Secondly, S Ranks, and advanced moves.  S Ranks on sub-levels, boss, and final boss levels are reached by getting a large score percentage in each level, it's possible to miss some thump pads and get damaged on some walls and still beat a section with an S rank.  S Ranks are not easy, you'll have to replay a sub-level multiple times in order to achieve it but is an excellent challenge for those willing to attempt it.  Advanced  moves range from perfect turns, stomping, and kills.  Perfect turns are preformed by pressing the arrow key at the last possible moment before reaching the wall and is rewarded by a higher score and a satisfying sound effect.  As you start to feel the rhythm of the levels these will start to become easier to perform.  Stomping is achieved by pressing up and holding spacebar when reaching a thump pad and pressing down instead of spacebar when reaching another thump pad.  If your score multiplier is 2x or 3x (shown in the top right and plays a sound when reached)  The player will spawn a glowing thump pad which can restore your shield if you lost it and has a marginal difference in score gain then regular thump pads.  If you thump on a glowing thump pad in a sub-level the game will temporarily pause and spawn another thump pad, giving you a small amount of extra time to view the track so you can act accordingly to the enviornment. Tentacles growing on the track can actually be destroyed!  By stomping on any thump pad tentacles that are in front of you will be killed which both clears the screen giving you more vision of the track and adds to your score at the end (displayed by Kills x #).  

Lastly, issues and closing thoughts.  Two of my major gripes with the game is the lack of an option to display your score on the hud, and that [b][strike]you need to restart the level from the beginning if you get an A or worse while attempting the (All S Rank) challenge.  The game provides you with a quick restart button "R" which allows you to restart a sub-level but should provide the player with a way to re-do "failed" levels to not deliberately waste yout time and erase your progress.  This happened to me several times and would've completed every level with an S rank more quickly if the option to re-do levels was implemented.[/strike][/b] (SEE EDIT)  Overall I enjoyed beginning to end in the game, the game seems fairly linear and limited at first but will introduce new concepts and unique boss types/changing final boss that both challenge and interest the player.  I recommend the game particularly for those who are accustomed to and seek challenge and for those who would like to try a difficult game out.  Below is the S Rank for Level 9 for those interested (Spoiler warning)!

http://steamcommunity.com/sharedfiles/filedetails/?id=784915834

EDIT 11/4/2016: You can now restart from the previous sub-level if you get a score that's less than an S so I only have one gripe with the game now, it's a shame this change couldn't have come on launch day but it's a much appreciated and welcome change.  Good job devs!

Have a great day!

26138456.review:
Challenging and visually appealing, was positively surprised. Would recommend to anyone who's into rhythm games.   
Having said that, there's some minor problems that you should keep in mind before buying.  

- Thumper is designed around chasing highscores.   
The first reason is the way of "clearing" levels. You clear a level by reaching the next checkpoint, but this can be simply done by ignoring most of the objects and only avoiding real obstacles. All you need to do to progress, is to survive. This also applies to levels you'll face later on. Now of course this takes away the fun from a rhythm game and you wouldn't intentionally abuse this, but it will happen. 
The second reason is the amount of playtime needed to finish the game. After 6 hours I completed the game and all that is left, is to chase highscores on each level.   
   
- Some levels don't scale logically.  
The beginning is easy, the end is hard. But inbetween you might struggle on one final boss and clear the next with ease. The same applies to consecutive parts of a level. I couldn't help but feel like some parts were just added as fillers or simply placed in the wrong level.  

Considering that some aspects of Thumper could use some more fine-tuning, I would still recommend the game as a whole. But if you're not the kind of person who tries to get the highest scores, I'd suggest you wait until the game is on sale.

26137441.review:
Thumper is as though someone took the foundations of Amplitude or Audiosurf but took the genre in a different direction. Crafting levels and songs that complement each other perfectly and increasing difficulty by adding new mechanics and obstacles to overcome rather than increasing BPM and notes.
Interestingly, Thumper is not unlike a shoot 'em up game in some ways. A niche game in a niche genre, to be sure, and while those who pick up the game casually might prioritize "merely" surviving checkpoint to checkpoint (a fun and very challenging task requiring a good ear and better processing speed/reflexes), the game is a scoring challenge at heart. The game becomes more about strategy and balancing risk/reward so one can safely complete an entire level while maximizing score without losing health, dropping a beat or having to rely on a checkpoint and losing score multipliers. 

Hopefully, the devs will continue fine-tuning the small annoyances (a task they have done very well at so far) and add additional content (perhaps in the form of DLC tracks) and propel the game to the masterpiece status it deserves.

26135260.review:
There are two problems with this game :
- The "song" or "track" you're supposed to follow, is playing its sound 1-2 seconds in advance, so that you can predict by listening what you will have to do. BUT this "track" is just too low in volume to be heared when playing, as you also produce sound by correctly following the track.  
I think the reasoning behind it, was the track should be playable the first time you play. 
But in doing that, there is a lot of frustration comming from it, as you are constantly trying to appreciate the feeling of correctly playing the track, but at the same time concentrating on listening the 1 seconds offseted track you're suppose to play.
- The visuals effects are very annoying to estimate distance between you and the next "thing" you should tap onto.
This is produce situation where in 7 levels you're estimating the distance without thinking, and just at the boss level, each time you successfully hit him you fail miserably at the first "thing" you should tap.
The track shaking is the best example of it.

26125578.review:
An insanely polished score-chasing rhythm/action game with a high-ish difficulty curve.

Even if you don't typically play games to get high scores, each level can be difficult enough to take some time on its own, depending on your reflexes. Controlling your chrome beetle feels great, there are generally enough cues to let you know what's ahead and everything about the sound and visuals is vaguely unsettling.

There aren't too many mechanics to learn, but they are enough to keep things interesting throughout every level and for only using one button, they manage quite a lot. Occasionally the difficulty curve can be uneven, you can start a level having a hard time, then the middle is relatively manageable but then it goes back to being very difficult at the end. Most of the time it's pretty consistent though.

Thumper has a ton of replay value too, given that you're ranked in every section of every level it does well to make you want that "S" rank, not only with the score but also when you hit every obstacle, it adds to the soundtrack, like a strange extra drum beat.

I've been waiting for this for a good long while and I'm so, so glad that it's satisfying. 100% recommended and I would be totally on board for a sequel. Also, thanks for not copping out and giving a "USE A CONTROLLER" splash screen. It plays perfectly fine on a keyboard.

26120368.review:
A visually stunning rythm game. Every 'thump' feels incredibly powerful and in later levels when executing a string of thumps and turns perfectly just makes your adrenaline go wild.

The difficulty scales well in my opinion, but I do have a lot of experience with rythm games. People who don't might struggle a bit more on the earlier levels. Luckily there are many checkpoints and restarting happens in a smooth continuous fashion. Dying is not as frustrating as in other rythm games.

Because it's a fairly new game there are some bugs and issues. But the development team is bringing regular updates which solve the most requested issues. I myself posted a technical issue and received an answer in less than two days.

26115756.review:
- La carrera fractal -

Thumper es sin duda, una de las grandes sorpresas del año para mi. Hacía ya un tiempo que no jugaba a algo que solo utilizara un botón de acción; todas las acciones rítmicas se llevan a cabo con las direcciones y un botón. Es tan simplista en mecánicas que ni te lo tienen que explicar, enseguida entiendes el propósito.

Como juego musical rápidamente se conjuga con la acción: hay jefes, e incuso puedes matar fractales, tentáculos y trozos de escenario haciendo combos. No sabes en ningún momento si te estás guiando por el sonido, por la vista, o por la memoria (o todo a la vez), pues el ensayo y el error es necesario, sobre todo, si queremos la S, puntuación perfecta. Para este propósito existen checkpoints al final de cada pequeña fase o tramo. Hay 9 mundos subdivididos en fases, si mueres, reapareces al principio de esa fase. El objetivo es cruzar los aros intentando tomar bien las curvas, saltando los obstáculos, rompiendo aquellos que se puedan, pulsando también las luces del suelo, que son las que permiten que saltemos o matar a los jefes.

El juego adquiere un frenetismo y una exigencia muy alta ya a partir del mundo 6, añadiendo hasta aquél reglas nuevas: cada mundo es como el anterior pero aprendiendo una nueva mecánica, que se conjugarán de foma endiablada ya por el final. Ojalá bastase sólo el oído, esa es la mala noticia: Thumper no es un juego rítmico sin más. Es una aventura, una carrera donde la vista y los reflejos de tus pulgares es casi más importante que lo que se oye. 

Los jefes son una auténtica pasada: han creado un género nuevo con esto. Para poder matarlos hay que hacer las secuencias correctamente hasta que aparezca el disparador. A los 4 golpes, el jefe muere. Tu escarabajo cibernético puede morir de dos simples golpes, pero podemos recuperarnos en ciertos puntos. Más adelante lucharás más por memorizar dónde recuperarte que en hacer los tramos a la perfección. En ese ámbito el juego suma más del triple y cuádruple de horas, a más exigente quieras ser, a más elegante quieras realizar tu partida, más horas te demandará Thumper.

Una banda sonora contundente y que va dando pistas de los elementos que van a aparecer, ya que se basa en la música. Pero que no os engañen; hay que tener mucho más énfasis en lo que se ve que en lo que se oye. Con todo ello, un trabajo supremo.

Thumper es el juego de acción perfecto camuflado tras una propuesta melódica. Es un viaje psicodélico y adrenalínico por el surrealismo, mundos fractales, geométricos y pesadillescos. No tengo muy claro si este juego surgió de un mal sueño, pero parece tejido con elementos que dan bastante mal rollo.

No siempre se necesita algo cinematográfico para sorprender. Thumper es simple, muy simple, y funciona a la perfección.

Phenomenal.
A simple wordless tutorial gets you started.
Immediately, you're struck with the blunt thump that will guide you through the rest of the game.

26088537.review: Thumper, while having absolutely no story, has simple, but extremely challenging gameplay. It's punishing when you don't follw its beat, but it is merciful if you can't get every point, and even then, you would have this really odd sensation to come back and perfect what you've missed. The psychedelic visuals of polygonal tunnels amidst a sky that resembles the Aurora Borealis, powerful time signatures with high-speed tempo, and bosses with complex rhythmic segments will make you question your sanity and sense of rhythm, but the satisfaction from defeating those bosses, getting every rhythm down, and overcoming obstacles you thought was otherwise impossible will assuredly keep you coming back for more. To those hungry for a challenge of reflex, rhythm and memory, you've come to the right place.

No game has demanded such intense concentration from me before. To THUMP perfectly you must THUMP yourself into a trance. This may take minutes, hours or days but once you reach that perfect zen of THUMP, you feel unstoppable. And it feels good!  

  The game requires undivided attention and punishes unmercifully, but the learning curve is very gradual and forgiving. If you're a fan of rhythm games it's a must-have hands down. There's more than enough replay value for the $20 price tag and it's a beautifully crafted game. The way the gameplay flows it's easy to have long play sessions and get stuck in the trance, however progress is saved fairly so if you need to dip out or are just plain overwhemled (some stages feel like an uncontrollable, never ending rollercoaster), then you aren't punished for taking a break. 

  Overall it's a game that demands love, attention and perfection but in the end it gives back as much as you put in. Highly recommended!

26071786.review:
[b]Absolute brutality.[/b]

That's how to describe this game. You don't just play a casual round of [i]Thumper[/i]. In fact you really don't 'play' this game as much as you hang on and let the experience throw you around. [b][i]Thumper[/i] is awesome.[/b] I don't think I've had an experience like this, maybe ever. 

Even after I watched the trailer and a few LetsPlay videos, I couldn't really 'get' what you do or what is going on. I'll try to explain. This isn't a rhythm game like [i]DDR[/i]. To a certain extent things go along to the beat, but from my experience, you really can't rely on that. This is more like an endless runner like [i]Boson X[/i] or something, where you hit a button at a certain event. You see a turn? Hit a direction plus 'A'. You see a solid marker on the ground, hit 'A' to jump. Things like this.

But what really sets this title apart is the experience. The music and sound is so badass. The levels are beautiful, and the controls are tight. [b]Playing with it loud is mandatory.[/b]

[b]Pros:[/b]
+Totally original experience as far as I'm concerned
+Music couldn't be more awesome, and this isn't typically my genre
+Tight controls, and this really matters here
+Awesome twitch-style gameplay where it's always your fault when you lose
+While 9(?) levels seems short, it's really not; after 2 hours I was at the end of level 2

[b]Cons:[/b]
-It [i]seems[/i] pricey, but IMO it is worth it
-Best played in long play sessions (not so much a 'con', but I thought I'd throw that out there)

[b]Wild experience.[/b] Even if you don't want to pay full price, you [i]need[/i] to try this at some point.

26070374.review: I bought this game as per a Reddit review, and I have to say, not a single thing he said was incorrect. This game was very well executed, pleasantly challenging, great music, and my god I love the style of the graphics. Most certainly worth the purchase.

26070291.review:
(More details on scoring and leaderboard at the end)

This is bloody brilliant.

It's one of the few games that I can see most people enjoying based on the gameplay alone, yet still manages to introduce something very alien and unique through its art (both in its audio and visuals).

The shortest description I can give is that it's something out of 2001: Space Odyssey? The weird part. The really, really crazy part.

And it's beautiful.


The game can get tough, but it never seemed unfair, to me. I really enjoyed the challenge and now I'm planning to go through it all over again several time to master it... why? Because the flow of the game is amazing. It's a rollercoaster, in many ways... But it's hard to judge it when you have to restart some levels repeatedly. I'm curious about how it would feel to go through it in one single run. ... It might take a while, though.


The music is very interesting, and probably not something for your mp3. Brian Gibson has a "noise rock" band, which is... noisy? The game itself is what I would call "noise classical", perhaps? Know the discordant violins in horror movies? That's a big of part of this.
The other part is the industrial/metallic tribal percussion.
It's strange, but it's perfect for the game.

The visuals are also very abstract and metallic, but very beautiful, in parts. Something harmonious, sometimes discordant as well. And always very alien.

The "feel" of the game is some of the best I've seen in any game... ever?
It's that good. If you string combos together, your hits become very powerful, complementing the strange rhythm of the music with the rhythm of the level, which are not always "cooperative".


I can't say much more about it, for now. But it's amazing!
If you're looking for a rhythm game in the vein of Guitar Hero or Stepmania, this is not at all for you. It's not about playing your own music... This game is its own beast. If you're not into its aesthetic (which I can imagine many people are not?), you will probably not enjoy the game very much... some people consider it all to blend together. I disagree, but I can see that happening, depending on what you're expecting. 

So yeah. If the videos seem cool, definitely get it. There's a lot more to the game than shown in the videos due to the visceral feeling and impact of the game.

So good!



P.S.: I've now beaten the game twice, to see how much it would change. On general terms, there's definitely replayability without wanting to climb the leaderboards. This is because you can still play the previous levels in a very different way by using the new mechanics that you didn't know when you first did the levels.
This can make some levels far, far, harder. But also much more satisfying! It's really cool to see how levels were designed in different ways depending on how much of the game you've played before.

The scoring system is also more complex than it first seemed.

There's a basic C-B-A-S "rank" for each sub-level, and then calculated for the full level. These mostly depend on your misses. S being for missing no "Thump".
You can't replay specific levels, at the moment, but you can restart the sub-level that you're playing. This means that you have to play the whole level from start to finish to get these rankings, but you can restart each one as much as you'd like before moving on.

The scoring, which will get you on the leaderboards, is where the real game is.
For these, restarting carries a penalty. So, to reach the top, you need to play every sub-level in a row, as well as you can, without restarting to get the optimal score for each one. It's a marathon, more so than a sprint.

I can see this being a somewhat controversial system, but I like it. It's the hardcore way to play the game, and I'm glad that there is one, rather than seeing how restarts the most.

For the score, you have to study the levels, somewhat, because of the "stomp" mechanic. On 2 consecutives Thumps, you can use the first to fly, and stomp the second for extra points. This is even more important in boss fights, where you're awarded multipliers for stomping the final thump (sorry for this vocabulary haha).

Aside from that, there are the riskier plays of trying to make a perfect curve, etc. (to get a perfect, you have a much narrower window to turn -- otherwise, you're dead).

It makes it much more interesting, choosing when to play aggressively or not, trying to get a good score. 


There's quite a bit of depth for those looking to climb leaderboards, so that's definitely another plus!


P.S.2: Consistency is way more important than I realized before. Each consecutive level you beat without a Miss gives up a 1+ multiplier. The same for No Damage levels. So your score really gets out of control if you can avoid missing/damage for many consecutive levels. It's good to keep the competition high!

One kinda big problem I have, though, has to do with the "game feel". I really like the whole impact the game conveys, but I think it takes a step too far by slowing down the game too much for give a very high impact in a long combo. This slow down actually throws me off completely, sometimes, because the rhythm breaks in these situations. So... you're expecting a certain obstacle at a certain time, but the tempo slows down a lot and then speeds up again. 
It leads to a rather inconsistent rhythm when you're actually doing great!
Which is a negative. Sure, it makes it harder to do perfect runs, but it essentially punishes good play? I would much rather have a lower impact in these long combos, but be able to keep the "flow", so to speak.

26052420.review:
■良い点について
粗削りだが中毒性あり。stage5までやった感想です。
WAVESのような雰囲気シューティングだなと感じます。WAVESを延々やれる人はハマれます。
音ゲーではないとは言い切れないが音ゲーだとも言えない感じ。
でも音は心地いい。疾走感はすさまじい。
ゲーム自体は単純なので死んでも何度も挑戦できるカジュアルさがあります。

■悪い点について
操作すべきタイミングは視覚・聴覚的に予告があるが、
ところどころマップの構成や背景との色の兼ね合いで理不尽さを感じる。
音楽・グラフィックともにバリエーションに乏しく、亜種らしきものしかない。

操作性にやや難あり。
他の方もおっしゃっていますが連打のように見えるノートは長押しで突破可能です。
直感的にわかりやすいかどうかはギリギリのラインです。
一応説明もありますがちょっと大雑把。
現在オプションにキーアサインの変更などはありません。
予告の音量だけ上げたいところですが、音量も全体の音量しかいじれないです。つらい。

最初はワンミスでゲームオーバーかと思ったのですが、装甲の概念があります。
一撃では死にません。

追記
ステージが進むにつれ理不尽さの方が勝ってしまいました。
最後まで遊ぶモチベーションは…ないかな…。

一生懸命連打するみたいなものは今のところ無し。

最初プレイした時は、上手くタイミング取れなくて全然面白くなかったが、慣れてきて感覚でタイミングを合わせられるようになったら一気に面白くなった。

ただし、慣れてきて音に合わせて確実な操作ができた時の爽快感は尋常ではありません。これは今までやってきたどんな音ゲーよりも素晴らしいです。

あえて欠点を挙げると、視覚上で装飾物と障害物の見分けが少しつきにくいことでしょうか。一瞬の認識ミスが大ダメージにつながるので、かなりつらいです。

26040091.review:
Thumper ist schwer. Zu diesem Zeitpunkt, 3-4 Tage nach dem Release haben bis jetzt nur 1,7% der Spieler alle Levels geschafft (laut Errungenschaften).

Es fühlt sich so gottverdammt gut an wenn die Eingaben aus den Fingern gleiten und man mit dem Rhytmus und den Effekten verschmilzt; Dieses Gefühl hatte ich lange nicht mehr bei einem Spiel. Diesen Flow kenne ich bisher wirklich nur von Rhythm Games oder wenn ich Instrumente spiele. Von daher denke ich, dass der Begriff "Rhythmus-Actionspiel" ziemlich gut passt. 

Man misst sich über Ranglisten mit der Welt. Die anfänglichen Level lassen nicht viel kompetetiven Platz, jedoch bieten die späteren Level viel Raum für Geschick und Reaktionszeit.

Es gibt zwei handvoll Levels, die nach und nach neue Elemente reinbringen. Das Momentum fühlt sich gut an und mit der Zeit kommen immer schwierigere Herausforderungen. Diese neu kennengelernten Elemente lassen sich auch in den früheren Levels integrieren - somit hat man einen Wiederspielwert indem man seine Punktzahl nachträglich erhöhen kann. Zudem kann man die alten Levels dann in einem neuen Licht sehen. :c)

Thumper ist eine intuitive und coole Erfahrung, die ihr euch nicht entgehen lassen solltet.

100%ig einer meiner Favoriten von 2016.

26039234.review:
Thumper is a great game. It's also an incredibly hard game. If you get frustrated easily, you will not like this game. I had to actually sit back and take a break to prepare myself after I failed the world 1 final boss a dozen times in a row. This game has nine worlds. If that sounds intimidating, that's because it is. I honestly don't think I will be able to finish this game completely.

The game's aesthetic is quite pleasant, IMO. The beetle/color scheme looks like something off of a Journey album, and I love it. The music and animations are very harsh (hence the term rhythm violence), and it really serves to set the atmosphere for this game. It's incredible how this game can be so colorful, yet so dark and intimidating at the same time.

Bottom line: If you like rhythm games (and are pretty good at them), this is a no-brainer. It's very polished, and the controls are extremely simple; it's just the timing that will kill you. Over and over again...
